“Oh? There weren’t any lesbians in that movie.”

“No,” Alice said with a shrug, “Wanda got the role and then asked if her husband could become her wife and… she got Rio hired.”

Rio was staring determinedly at her own knee now, only vaguely aware of the conversation around her and Agatha as she reached over to fill her own glass again.

“It’s cute actually,” Alice said with an innocent smile, “They’ve hired a kid who looks like Rio. Not as much as Nicky, obviously. Agatha, ever thought about putting Nicky to work?”

But Rio looked up now and saw the fury in Agatha’s gaze before she managed to school it somewhat, shaking her hair back and settling back in her armchair.

“Rio and Wanda? With my child?”

Oh, Agatha was mad as hell. And Rio felt a sick sort of satisfaction for it.

But more than that, she had to stop herself from grabbing her friend to get her to stop digging a hole.

But Alice was oblivious, seeing only the logic in it where Agatha was seeing none of it.

“Yeah! He looks like Rio, he likes Rio. It would be a win win!”

Rio was surprised that Agatha’s glass hadn’t snapped in two in her hand and her gaze fell to it briefly before she raised her eyes back up to Agatha’s face and she cleared her throat softly.

Agatha’s gaze flickered to her before she looked away and took a deliberate sip of her wine.

“Nicky isn’t interested in acting.”

Not a lie, Rio assumed. But not the reason Nicky wouldn’t be playing the role of her and Wanda’s child.

“The poor pressure on the kid,” Jen said with a smile, “Imagine he wasn’t as good as his mother. That he didn’t get two Oscar’s by the time he was forty.”

“One,” Alice murmured quietly and Rio arched a brow, tearing her attention away from Agatha to briefly glance at her best friend.

“Let’s not fight. We know it’ll be Agatha.”

“Maybe,” Rio said slowly, looking back to Agatha and watching curiously as she flexed a muscle in her jaw. “It won’t be either of us and someone else will win. Maybe Wanda.”

Blue eyes flashed around to meet Rio’s teasing brown and Rio couldn’t believe that she’d spent so long thinking that Agatha wasn’t interested when she was practically about to explode upon the mere mention of Wanda.

That even now, when Agatha had told her they couldn’t continue, she was still jealous.

It felt too good to be true. And yet. Agatha looked mutinous.

“Her movie was a mess and her publicity-…”

“The photos of us in Venice?”

Agatha shot Rio a warning look that Jen caught and she leant forwards in her chair, frowning at them both.

“Wait. What am I missing? The two of you… something’s going on.”

Agatha’s face morphed into something else then, something closed off and Rio bit down in her lip before looking over at Jen and feigning ignorance she asked: “What do you mean?”

“There’s… something I picked up in Italy. And it’s happening again only it’s… different.”

“Huh,” Rio said with a raised brow, shifting in her seat to turn her body slightly more towards Alice.

She felt a little uneasy about this assessment and shot a subtle look to Agatha who had handled this a lot better than her and had shaken her hair out behind her again, looking directly at her best friend with an unamused expression.

“Didn’t you tell me to be nice to Rio for Alice’s sake?”

This was news to Rio. News she didn’t exactly welcome.

But she knew Agatha was playing her role perfectly.

Jen bristled a little and even Alice frowned at this news.

“Well… I said be nice. I didn’t say-…”

“Didn’t say what, Jen? Invite Rio over for dinner so Alice would feel more comfortable?”

Rio fought the urge to fidget where she sat but she couldn’t give over any more power. She’d already lost so much that night.

And that hurt more than she’d been prepared for.

“Well… maybe I said it but…”

Alice sat forwards slightly and Rio cleared her throat, “I can leave if it’s easier on everyone.”

“Don’t be ridiculous,” Alice said quickly, and Rio saw the panic in her eyes as she turned to her, her warm hand now resting on Rio’s bare knee.

But Alice’s wasn’t the reaction she wanted to check.

She turned to Agatha and saw that her eyes were focused on Alice’s hand resting against Rio and if she didn’t know any better she might think she looked jealous.

“Agatha?” She asked suddenly, wanting to know if this was really futile, if she were truly unwanted and unwelcome. “Do you want me to leave?”

It felt the way moving through thick snow felt.

Your body warm, hot, too hot even with the effort of it. Your feet and legs heavy as they tried to power your body through. Your lips stinging with the cold even as your cheeks flushed a soft pink. And Rio felt it then. Felt the heat and the heaviness and the sting.

She felt the incremental movement of Agatha’s eyes as she dragged them from where Alice’s hand still rested on her knee, up Rio’s torso and eventually, blessedly, meeting her gaze.

Rio’s stomach flipped at the sight of her.

At the softness in her gaze, at the gentle way she was looking at her, so different from just two minutes ago, at the twitch of her fingers as they rested on the armrest, ever so slightly stretching towards her.

And she shook her head. Twitched it only an inch to the side. But it was a shake nonetheless.

Rio felt like a hand had been released from around her throat and she had to look away from Agatha again. Suddenly unsure if she should have even asked; thinking maybe she should have just left.

“Well,” Jen started again, frowning suspiciously at her best friend, “now that’s sorted, can we go back to having a nice time please?”

Alice squeezed Rio’s knee and shot her a confused look before she pulled her hand back and cleared her throat.

“So, Heartburn next, right? Rio was desperate for that. But I think you’ll be incredible. I mean… you always are.”

Rio glanced sideways at Alice and then was brave enough to look back to Agatha and saw her smile tensely, her whole demeanour completed changed again.

She looked lost in the conversation, her mind elsewhere and determinedly not looking at Rio.

And Rio kept up appearances for the next five minutes, nodding and smiling as the two beside her on the couch picked up the slack and Agatha contributed even a little.

But Rio needed some air and so excused herself to go to the bathroom, ignoring the look on Alice’s face as she did.

She didn’t turn around to see Agatha’s face.

She made it down to the house before she realised she was being followed and turned just in time for Alice’s hand to curl around her arm and for her to whisper urgently, “What’re you doing?”

Rio just shrugged out of her hold and finished the route to the ground floor bathroom.

Once inside, with Alice slipping in behind her, she sighed heavily, “Nothing. Nothing’s happening.”

“It is. I thought you and Agatha were good. You both look distraught.”

Rio scoffed and went to the mirror, and saw some of what Alice was saying. She’d looked happier. She’d looked better.

“Rio, what happened?”

“Nothing.”

“Fine. Don’t tell me. Whatever. But please, whatever it is, try to fix it. We’re in such a good position with Agatha on side. Just… sort it out.”

Rio sighed again and dropped her head as Alice left her alone in the bathroom.

There was no use. It was pointless to think that she’d be able to fix this. She’d tried to reassure Agatha that her secret was safe with her and yet Agatha was lashing out, and then freezing her out completely and watching her like she’d been the one to break this off.

Like Rio was to blame.

Agatha was angry and sad and Rio didn’t know how to fix it because she felt exactly the same.

Only she couldn’t lash out because that would draw even more attention to it and Rio had already promised that what had happened between them would be safe as houses with her.

She wondered if she had just text back what might have been. Would Agatha have still pulled away? Still acted like she despised her?

But Rio Vidal hadn’t made it to where she was by cowering away.

She brushed down her dress and ran a hand through her hair and took one last look at herself before she stepped from the bathroom and strode back out.

She found that everyone had migrated to the kitchen, and even Ralph had made his unwelcome presence known again. Everyone was sat around the island with Agatha the other side chopping up leeks.

She didn’t look up when Rio entered the room.

“Ah the prodigal actress has returned,” Jen called out with a smirk, and Ralph hurried from his stool to offer it to Rio.

She wanted to refuse but suddenly she felt Agatha’s eyes on her again and so she took it, if only to keep the peace.

“Did I miss anything?”

Alice passed Rio her glass that she’d saved from outside and Rio accepted it with a small smile, taking a large sip to try and calm the nerves that were again bubbling in her chest.

“No, just-…”

The soft music playing in the background filtered into Rio’s conscious then as the infamous chords struck up.

The world slowed and Rio’s gaze landed on Agatha and she saw that she’d recognised it too.

Her knife slipped and she cut a gash in her right thumb as Lindsey Buckingham’s voice filled the room.

“Loving you, isn’t the right thing to do.”

Rio stood as Agatha gasped and raised her bleeding thumb to her mouth to quell the bleed and she moved around to take her to the sink and help her rinse it.

“Ah! Rio, I’m fine.”

“Here,” Rio insisted calmly, barely thinking as she held Agatha’s hand gently under the cool water.

“Just rinse it.”

“You okay, hon?” Ralph asked from somewhere behind them and Rio felt sick as Agatha’s fingers curled around her own.

“Fine. Turn the damn song off,” Agatha huffed, even as her hold remained gentle against Rio.

Rio glanced at her before she pulled away and saw that Agatha looked far from the distant and angry she’d seemed earlier and instead looked pained. And Rio didn’t think it was because of the cut.

“Bandaids?” She asked quietly, only vaguely aware that the song had now changed and talk had picked up behind them.

“Second drawer on the right.”

Rio nodded and went to dry her hands on a dish cloth nearby before she sought a bandaid in a neatly laid out drawer.

She initially grabbed a normal looking box full of them and then spotted a second box with different images on it and smiled to herself as she rummaged to find what she was looking for.

She returned to Agatha’s side with a paper towel to help dry the area and the special bandaid she’d picked for the occasion.

Agatha winced a little at the light pressure of the towel against the small cut but Rio mumbled, “It should heal quickly. It’ll just sting for a bit.”

“You seem to know an awful lot about first aid.”

“Grew up with permanently grazed knees.”

Agatha hummed and Rio caught her smiling a little before her gaze dropped to the bandaid now half on her thumb.

“Rio.”

“Yes?”

“I have an Oscar.”

“Yes.”

“Those are Nicky’s.”

“Then he has good taste.”

Rio lifted Agatha’s hand to inspect her handiwork and smirked up at Agatha, looking past her new addition to her thumb of a bandaid covered in cowboy hats and grinning at her.

“Juvenile.”

“Mm.”

Rio had to resist the urge to kiss the patient and instead behaved herself and released Agatha’s hand to return to her stool, making brief eye contact with Agatha again before she took a sip of wine.

The rush of being close, of touching Agatha was unlike anything else she’d ever felt before.

And she now found it difficult to look away.

The power of Fleetwood Mac and the witchy wonder of a song written for Stevie Nicks having cast a spell that broke the tension between them, that seemed to bring Agatha back out of herself, that made Rio wonder if she’d maybe change her mind and if Rio would allow it.

But she took another sip of wine and her eyes fell to Agatha’s thumb now sporting the cowboy bandaid and she knew she’d allow it.

She’d beg for it if she had to.

But she kept herself from looking at Agatha properly again as the conversation picked back up and Rio began to relax.

Maybe it was the wine.

Maybe it was the promise that maybe hope wasn’t dead.

Maybe it was that in spite of everything that had happened that night, Agatha had kept her promise of Rio sitting next to her at the table.

The excuse was that from this positioning it would be easier for her to get up to serve the food and easier for Ralph to fetch the wine.

Though Rio’s seat would have been good enough for either of these tasks.

No one said anything. Rio because she wanted to sit beside Agatha, Ralph because he wanted to sit at the head of the table, and Alice and Jen because all they cared about was sitting together.

Rio managed to keep her end of the shared conversation up, managed to not let the side down or Alice down.

The food was plentiful and good. Agatha, despite her minor injury, had made a puy lentil dish with roasted chicken thighs and Rio wondered if there was anything she wasn’t good at because she was three for three right now.

Acting, cooking, fucking.

But when it was time for more wine to be poured and dessert to be offered Rio felt a hand against her thigh and she had been so focused on watching Ralph stand after cracking a stupid joke about doing the hardest job at the table “keeping the glasses filled” that she jumped in her seat and whacked her knee against the underside of the table.

Everyone turned to look at her and even Ralph’s smile faded as he eyed Rio curiously.

“What the fuck, Vidal?” Jen asked with a scowl as Rio blushed furiously and cleared her throat, aware of the dangerous territory she’d just placed herself and Agatha in.

“Ever get one of those weird shivers?” She asked, pulling it straight out of her ass.

“I had an old friend say they happened when someone walked over your grave.”

“Riiiight,” Jen said slowly, toying with the stem of her empty glass.

Alice just scoffed out a laugh and shook her head in amusement, but kept her gaze on Rio as she settled down a little and rubbed at her knee with a frown.

Agatha didn’t make another move again until after the final bites of key lime pie had been eaten and the bowls pushed away from the happy diners and they sat and luxuriated in their fullness for a while, now all happily talking about their plans for the next little while with filming picking up for both Rio and Agatha soon.

It happened more cautiously this time, with Agatha shifting her seat a little under the pretence of getting closer to the table.

She’d brushed her fingers along the side of Rio’s thigh as she pulled back in and Rio cleared her throat quietly as she adjusted her weight to lean forwards on her elbows, providing slightly more cover if Agatha were to try again.

She didn’t. Not until Alice said that they should probably be going.

“No, stay,” Agatha said with a frown, her hand reaching out to brush Rio’s leg again even as she kept her gaze on Alice.

“It’s not that late.”

“I know but,” Alice started but Jen finished for her: “Agatha, Alice is leaving for months in two days. No offence and this was lovely but I’d like some alone time with her if you know what I mean.”

Rio laughed and Alice rolled her eyes at her but looked thrilled all the same.

Agatha’s hand pulled away and Rio felt like she could breathe properly again.

“I should get going too. But can I help with anything?”

Alice raised her brows at this offer but said nothing as she pushed her chair back and Jen did too.

“No, nothing.”

It was the first time Agatha had properly addressed Rio since the thumb incident earlier and Rio turned to look at her, seeing the softness return where she’d earlier assumed she’d never get to see that from Agatha again.

But she had to look away, had to keep playing her role.

So she stood with the others and they all made their way to the centre of the house, grabbing bags and keys and Rio hung back as the others said their goodbyes.

She couldn’t bring herself to be embraced by Ralph so she was quick to offer her hand, and shook it firmly even as he blinked in surprise at her.

But then she turned to Agatha and before thinking much she wrapped her arms around her and heard a soft whisper in her ear: “Get home safe.”

Rio could only nod, only smile falsely as she turned away for fear she’d ask to stay.

And when she hit the cooler air of the late night with Jen and Alice in tow she sucked in a heavy breath, and tried to calm her traitorous heart as it screamed at her to turn around and take one last look at Agatha Harkness.

Chapter End Notes

Next chapter already written soooo 👀

I had to chop a lot of Ralph out of this and eventually just made him disappear for a while because I can’t stand him which is annoying because I created him

And poor Agatha needs to get a grip on her emotions

Also saying “bandaid” as a British person feels ridiculous and I’m unsure why that felt right to do but I keep writing “mum”

Chapter 15: Breaking &amp; Entering

Chapter Summary

Someone breaks into Rio’s house and she loses something precious.

Agatha discovers a new hobby.

Chapter Notes

If I have something written it’s impossible for me not to post it so a lil pre-weekend treat for you all

Your comments and interest in this story make my day so please keep them coming I love them (and you) so much

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Rio woke with a headache.

One she knew wasn’t due to the amount of wine she’d had the night before.

One she knew was everything to do with heartache.

Falling for a married woman was never going to be a good idea.

Falling for Agatha Harkness was always going to be the worst idea.

She flung her arm out from the safety of the covers and found her phone on the side. It was 9:30am, just late enough to be considered a lie in, just early enough for Rio to want to turn over and stay in bed.

But this was her final day before she had to fly to Toronto tomorrow. And with a pang she realised that this time tomorrow she’d be landing soon.

Shaking the impending travel day with Alice barking orders in her ear and inevitably questioning her on the Agatha situation, she forced herself to get up and take a shower.

The water helped. The heat helped.

She stepped from it reluctantly, deciding a huge water bill wasn’t something she wanted to add to her troubles.

Her mind was on the chores she had to do today because as mindless and dull as they were, they at least took up the space sorrowful blue eyes and tentative touches were currently taking.

But there was a noise.

A loud noise that sounded like her front door opening.

Alice.

She groaned and grabbed a towel from the side, snaking it around herself and tucking it in tightly above her left breast.

She brushed her wet hair back with a ridiculous brush that her hair stylist had once gifted her and promised it would help to keep her locks ‘shiny and sleek’. She wasn’t sure what that meant or how a brush could manage it but she liked the guy so now had incorporated the brush into her daily routine.

It was as she placed the brush down that she heard her bedroom door open and promptly close.

She rolled her eyes.

And then, there was silence.

Alice was never silent.

Instinctively, her fingers curled around the brush again and she remained still, listening intently for any sign that Alice was simply speaking to her but quietly, which in itself would be unusual.

Deciding she had to face the music whether it was a man in a balaclava or her annoyed best friend, she ripped the door open and came face to face with someone she wasn’t expecting.

The expensive magic brush slipped from her fingers and she gaped at the sight before her.

Agatha Harkness was standing just a foot from the bathroom door, looking a little surprised herself that she were there.

And Rio thought her heart would never recover from the shock.

Not to mention the cruel way Agatha had decided to dress for the occasion.

She stood, brazen and bold, in a matching lilac gym set: a sports bra and leggings. Her hair was loose about her shoulders and she carried a light tote bag over her shoulder.

“You leave your front door unlocked?”

Rio blinked, her eyes darting up from where they’d been admiring the sight of toned thighs beneath the stretchy fabric of Agatha’s leggings.

“I locked it.”

“Clearly not.”

“You took it as an invitation to just… walk in?”

“I knocked,” Agatha said as if that were any excuse for walking into someone’s home.

Rio had so many questions, had so many things she needed to say, that being so full with words she found herself unable to say any of them.

It felt like her brain had short circuited. That one of her many fantasies she’d had about Agatha Harkness being in her bedroom had accidentally spilled into real life.

“I wanted to see you before you left,” Agatha offered as if she’d plucked one of the questions from Rio’s swirling brain and decided to answer it.

Rio’s mouth was open and she closed it quickly, aware she looked a little dumb standing silently with dripping hair and in a damp towel.

“How did you find out where I lived?”

Not the most important question, but one she was able to form.

Agatha’s brow quirked, as if she too knew this wasn’t exactly the question Rio wanted to ask.

“Jen.”

Rio nodded just once and swallowed, feeling a blush creep up her cheeks as her eyes dropped to the abs on display before her.

“Are you going for a workout?”

“Pilates. At ten.”

And Rio nodded again, forcing herself to look at the floor to try and sort her scrambled brain. But all she could think about was how lucky the rest of Agatha’s Pilates class were to see her dressed like this, bending and stretching and holding. It made her want to die.

Agatha took a step closer, and Rio’s eyes darted to the bag that she dropped by her feet as she did.

“I wanted to talk to you,” Agatha said, quieter this time.

“I think you said everything you wanted to yesterday.”

Rio cleared her throat and raised her gaze to Agatha again, seeing a brief flicker of fear in blue eyes before it disappeared and she instead looked soft again.

Much softer than she’d looked when she was telling Rio it was over. That it had been a mistake.

Agatha stepped closer and Rio sucked in a breath, moving so her back was against the frame of the bathroom door and her chin raised to challenge Agatha.

But she didn’t back down.

She stepped in and placed a hand on Rio’s cheek, her fingers just grazing the wet hair on the side of her head and her thumb tracing over still damp skin.

Rio felt the fire ignite in her again. She felt the pull of Agatha tighten its silky promise around her heart and she leant into her touch without meaning to, even as her mind caught up and said the lie she’d been telling herself since entering Agatha’s home yesterday evening:

“You were right yesterday. It was a mistake.”

Agatha’s brow furrowed slightly, even as her free hand moved up to hold Rio’s face properly, her touch so warm and welcome that Rio almost melted into her.

Her hands betrayed her and moved so her fingers could rest gently at Agatha’s hips and she sucked in a soft breath at the feel of her skin above the waistband of her leggings.

Agatha’s lips parted and Rio’s gaze fell to them, wondering if she’d ever see lips so perfect again, so beautifully crafted and so soft to the touch.

“A mistake I won’t make with anyone else. And a mistake I’d like to make properly, with you.”

Rio was shaken from her reverie, pulled back into her body as she raised her gaze to Agatha’s blue eyes, seeing an earnestness there that for now, at least, was all she needed to incline her head ever so slightly.

Even in her petulant mood the night before, she wouldn’t have denied Agatha.

But Agatha gave her a second’s grace in case she changed her mind. But her lips were now parted and blue eyes were now on Rio’s lips.

Rio breathed in slowly as Agatha closed the distance between them.

It was different this time, kissing Agatha.

It wasn’t new or frightening. Or rushed and soft. It was needy and desperate.

Agatha’s fingers moved to hold Rio’s head and Rio’s wrapped firmly around Agatha’s hips to press them flush together.

And Rio moaned unwittingly when she tasted Agatha’s tongue again for the first time since their dalliance on the couch.

But she didn’t have to be quiet anymore.

And Agatha clearly didn’t want her to be if the press of her hips or the nails digging into her scalp were anything to go by.

Rio’s hands moved down to grip Agatha’s ass at the same time that Agatha introduced her teeth to Rio’s lips and bit down harshly and Rio moaned as she opened her eyes to see Agatha looking at her with eyes the colour of midnight.
