“Noted. I love you too.”

Rio left Alice to walk off towards the uber that had just arrived to take her to the airport and she felt her body shrink in on itself a little, feeling at ease now she was alone and had no secrets to keep.

The drive back to her home took less than an hour and she found herself singing along to random Christmas songs played by the local radio station.

They were cheesy but they were better than sitting in silence with her thoughts or scrolling through her podcast app trying to find something she could be bothered to focus on.

She slammed the car door shut and made her way into her home, the smell of fresh cooking filling her lungs as she closed the door behind her.

“¡Hola! Mamá, papá!”

A bag on the console table by the door caught her eye but she ignored it, assuming it was an old tote bag of hers and perhaps her mum had used it to go pick up some last minute groceries.

But what really surprised her was that no one had shouted back.

She dropped her keys into the little bowl on the side and slowly moved through the house, looking this way and that until her last resort was to head out to the back to see if they’d taken themselves out to enjoy wait remained of the December sun.

“Rio!”

Rio raised her brows when she came round the side of the house and saw her parents sitting on the little bench with two chairs she recognised from her dining room sitting opposite them and a blanket stolen from her bed lying on the floor before them with the remnants of what looked like a picnic.

“¿Qué pasó?”

Anna Vidal looked up with a wide smile where she sat beside her husband, cradling one of Rio’s large mugs in her hands.

“We had guests.”

“Guests?”

“Invitadas,” her dad confirmed with a wink.

Rio raised her brows as she surveyed the evidence of these guests. She sat in one of the seats as her mum offered an explanation.

“Your friend arrived with gifts an hour after you left with Alice.”

“Amiga bonita,” her dad added unhelpfully but Rio shot him a small smile, wracking her brains for who was in town and who might stop by the day before Christmas Eve.

Wanda?

“She had gifts and her son wanted to see you.”

Agatha.

“Mom, was it Agatha?”

Rio’s heart rate went through the roof and she wondered how long it would be before her Apple Watch buzzed and told her she was working out.

But her mum seemed to not notice and was taking a sip of tea before responding.

“Sí, sí, Agatha y Nicky.”

If Rio hadn’t been sitting she might have fainted.

“They…”

Her gaze dropped to the remnants of the picnic and she saw suddenly the telltale signs of a demolished plate of tostones along with guac and a bowl that definitely at some point earlier had had ice cream in it.

“You need to buy some furniture.”

“Mamá,” Rio insisted suddenly, keen to find out everything about how and why Agatha and Nicky had been in her house with her parents when she’d had no knowledge that they were even coming.

“How long did they stay?”

“¡Bah!” Anna exclaimed with a laugh and a wave of her hand, “Long enough to teach the little one how to make tostones and for your papá to bore Agatha to death with tales of your childhood.”

Rio felt sick again.

“Dad,” she said and turned to see her dad smiling at her and had to look away for fear she’d relent instead of remaining firm in her quest for details.

“So? What? Hours?”

“Sí.”

Rio ran a hand through her hair and cleared her throat.

“What’s wrong, mija? I’m sure if you called you could-…”

“How was she? Was she…?”

“Encantadora, educada, nerviosa.” Charming, polite, nervous.

“Nervous?”

“Ella se calmó.” She calmed down.

Rio nodded slowly and felt her father’s eyes on her even as she focused in on her mom.

“And Nicky?”

Anna looked to her husband and then turned back to Rio slowly, a small frown appearing on her face, “Él tiene tu cara.” He has your face.

“I know,” Rio said in a much softer tone than before.

“Was he okay?”

“Shy. He was looking for you.”

Rio could only nod, and took a second to process all this before she spoke again, “Did you like them?”

“Very much.”

“¿Quién no lo haría?” Who wouldn’t?

Rio smiled a little and dropped her gaze to a lone breadstick in a cup and took it.

“You’ll spoil dinner.”

“I’m starving.”

Really she just wanted something to do.

Anna hummed and Rio smiled as she took a big bite.

“You don’t want to look at your gifts?”

She almost choked.

“Gifts?” She spluttered, her dad moving to come around and smack her back to help.

“Gracias,” she mumbled as she cleared her throat loudly, “What g-…?”

But her mom had said Agatha had brought gifts and she almost choked again but this time on nothing. She stood and looked at her dad who was smiling warmly at her with raised brows and she caught something in his eye that told her everything she needed to know about what Miguel Vidal had guessed already.

“They’re under the tree,” her mom said with a wave of her hand and Rio nodded, turning back to shoot her a smile before she disappeared inside, moving so fast she was practically jogging.

Once back inside Rio took a deep breath and placed her hand over her heart to feel it thrumming it’s thumping rhythm against her ribcage.

Weeks and weeks of nothing and then this. Showing up to her house with gifts, with Nicky. Staying and chatting with her dad. Her mom taking the time to teach Nicky how to cook.

It didn’t make sense.

She moved to the tree and crouched beside it, immediately knowing the gifts that must be from Agatha.

Since childhood she’d had a bad habit of feeling and shaking her gifts, ripping them just enough to be able to see what she had before Christmas morning.

It was a habit her parents tried to shake her out of but one she’d never truly beaten.

And each gift dotted around the foot of the tree had small rips in them, evidence of Rio’s impatience.

Only two gifts at the front looked untouched.

And both had cards leaning against them.

Under no circumstances did Rio think she could wait two days to find out what they were so she picked the first card up and recognised immediately the handwriting of a seven year old.

Her name was written in large, wobbling letters and there was a small sticker of Santa in the corner that smiled dispassionately up at her.

She smiled back at it and then turned it over to open it.

Inside was a slim photograph rather than the card she was expecting.

She pulled it out front first and saw that it was the picture Agatha had taken of her and Nicky; the one where their caps were backwards and Nicky was grinning up at Rio who grinned back down at him.

It was shocking, really, how long it had taken Rio to see the resemblance. But it was there. As bright and obvious as the smiles on their faces.

She turned it over and with a pang saw that Nicky had written her a message and Rio hadn’t thought to send anything to him.

Dear Rio, wishing you a very happy Christmas and a happy new year. Go Celtics! Love, Nicky.

She saw beneath the boy’s wobbly handwriting the faint pencil marks that must have been Agatha’s, guiding her son’s message.

Turning it back over to see their smiling faces again she had to swallow down the guilt she felt that not only had Nicky written to her, he’d wanted to see her.

And she’d not sent him anything.

She placed the card aside and took up the gift she assumed was from him, unwrapping it uncharacteristically gingerly until she held a brand new Celtics scarf in her hands.

She laughed as she draped it around her neck and turned then to the next card.

God she hoped there wasn’t a photo of Agatha in there.

She wasn’t sure she could handle seeing that right now.

She opened it blindly, having closed her eyes as she did so. Her fingers felt along the edges until she found it to be a card and she blinked down at the image that looked back at her.

The illustration was of a colourful little bay, drawn by an artist to represent Positano.

It was almost worse than an image of Agatha.

She opened it to see loopy handwriting, much neater than her son’s.

Rio, Merry Christmas. You once told Nicky the color green was lucky. I hope this has some luck in it too. Agatha.

Rio frowned at the message, her forefinger tracing the loops of Agatha’s signature and feeling the soft indent of her pen there.

Any remnant of Agatha was now precious.

She put the card aside to pick up the gift that had been left beneath it and opened that in the same way she had Nicky’s.

Inside the neat wrappings was a box with the initials HW on the front.

Harry Winston.

Rio hesitated before she opened it, knowing that whatever was inside would be beautiful and expensive.

And it was.

Sitting on a deep navy cushion was a gold pendant necklace, with a perfectly round emerald encased by a gold setting. It was delicate and Rio touched it equally delicately, wondering when Agatha had decided she’d buy her a gift, wondering when she’d decided she’d buy her this gift.

“Rio! You bad child,” came her mom’s voice from the other end of the room, “You cannot open gifts now!”

Rio barely reacted and chewed on her lip as she closed the little box and picked up the cards and the wrappings.

“I need to shower and then I’ll be down for dinner, okay?”

Her mom just waved a hand in dismissal and Rio disappeared up the stairs with her treasures, depositing the discarded wrappings in the trash as she went.

When in her room she jumped on her bed and lay out her gifts before her like a collector admiring her latest finds.

She stared at each one in turn, wondering why it hadn’t crossed her mind to even send a card. To at least buy Nicky something.

But then, she supposed, never in a million years had she assumed Agatha would give her a gift.

She pulled her phone out and ignored the texts and calls that filled her home screen and found Agatha’s contact in WhatsApp.

7:14pm
Rio Vidal: I didn’t get the memo about exchanging gifts.

Simple. Casual. Letting Agatha know she knew she should have sent something.

She placed her phone down just as the response came through.

7:15pm
Agatha Harkness: A strange way to say thank you.

7:16pm
Rio Vidal: I should be saying sorry. I hear you spent the afternoon with my parents

7:16pm
Agatha Harkness: They were great.

Rio chewed on her lip, her thumbs doing their familiar dance over the keypad as she leant over her phone.

7:19pm
Rio Vidal: Can you tell Nicky I’m sorry I missed him?

7:22pm
Agatha Harkness: I will.

Agatha wasn’t giving much. But this was the first she’d heard from Agatha in weeks and she wasn’t willing to let it go so easily.

The lightweight metal of her battered iPhone felt suddenly heavy in her hands, suddenly precious because it was full of Agatha.

Casting aside her fear that Agatha might not even respond, she pressed on:

7:23pm
Rio Vidal: Why would I need luck?

7:24pm
Agatha Harkness: Your mom warned me you might open your gifts.

7:24pm
Rio Vidal: It’s beautiful

7:25pm
Agatha Harkness: The scarf or the necklace?

7:26pm
Rio Vidal: Both. Can I call you?

7:26pm
Agatha Harkness: My mother and in-laws are here.

7:27pm
Rio Vidal: I’ll see you at the CCAs?

7:27pm
Agatha Harkness: Yes.

7:28pm
Rio Vidal: Te veo

Rio put her phone down after that. Her gaze falling to the Harry Winston box and the image of Positano next to it.

She longed to be alone with Agatha again. Even if she couldn’t touch her. Just to see how she was. Just to know she was okay.

If she’d been nervous when she’d arrived earlier that day then that had to mean something. It had to mean she didn’t know how Rio would have received her.

It had to mean she cared.

Or she wouldn’t have brought her son. Wouldn’t have helped him write her card. Wouldn’t have gone to the trouble of picking theIr picture and getting it printed so Rio could keep it.

Wouldn’t have chosen Rio a necklace.

Rio spent the rest of the evening in a slight daze but tried her hardest to get more information out of her parents.

What she got was limited.

Yes: Agatha had spoken Spanish to them the whole time she was there.

Yes: her accent was good, yes she could teach Rio a thing or two about grammar.

Yes: Nicky had spoken a little in Spanish and where he couldn’t respond he’d used English.

Yes: he’d been shy all day.

Yes: every time the wind blew a certain way he’d turned to see if Rio had arrived home.

Yes: Agatha had taken Nicky away whilst Ralph entertained his parents and her mom.

No: she didn’t say much about it.

No: she hadn’t seemed bored or annoyed by her dad’s stories.

No: she didn’t try to leave quickly.

Yes: she’d asked how Rio had been.

It was flashes of an afternoon, delivered in rapid Spanish from her mother who was more interested in telling her about the family’s drama.

But it was all Rio had.

Agatha had told her she needed some time and Rio was giving her that. But she didn’t know how much time she had left in her.

But time moved still and before she could blink it was Christmas.

And Christmas Day was a soft day. A day where she could be in her pyjamas. A day where she’d felt emboldened by two mimosas with breakfast to send a photo to Agatha that went unanswered until the early evening.

She’d put her new necklace on even as she still wore her ratty old University of Delaware t-shirt and thrown the scarf artfully over herself too.

And she’s smiled like she might have done if the gifts had been handed to her personally by the people who’d bought them for her.

And in the soft lightning of her bedroom she’d sent the selfie; makeup free, and hopeful.

The response came much much later than she’d hoped it would.

9:13pm
Agatha Harkness: Green is your color.

Rio had been doom scrolling when the message came through, laid out on the sofa with a hoodie on over the pyjamas she’d been in all day. Her stomach was full and her wine glass was tragically empty but she could neither be bothered to refill it or bring herself to ask her mom watching Love Actually or rouse her sleeping dad in the armchair to get it for her.

Plenty of messages had been streaming through all day but this was the first she clicked into.

9:15pm
Rio Vidal: How has your day been?

9:17pm
Agatha Harkness: Fine. Yours?

9:17pm
Rio Vidal: Quiet

Rio chewed on her lip as she waited for a reply but minutes went by and nothing and so she pulled her hood up and sulked silently about it, wondering if she should have been more witty or asked another question.

At the top of her spiral another text came through:

9:33pm
Agatha Harkness: What’re you doing?

9:33pm
Rio Vidal: I’m on the couch. Mom’s watching Love Actually

9:35pm
Agatha Harkness: Maybe next year she’ll be watching your Christmas movie.

Rio frowned at this message, unsure what Agatha was referring to until her wine-slowed brain kicked into gear again.

9:38pm
Rio Vidal: Can’t believe you passed on it

9:40pm
Agatha Harkness: I have taste.

Rio smirked at her phone and danced her thumbs for a bit before she tapped back:

9:41pm
Rio Vidal: In necklaces, in women

The risk hadn’t paid off.

Agatha didn’t text back.

Rio sulked more and eventually took herself off to bed by ten thirty.

By the time Alice was back and the new year was celebrated with her parents leaving the day before, and with a messy, loud, house party to ring in the bells, Rio had blocked out her last, regrettable text to Agatha.

She’d been drunk out of her mind entering the new year and had just one more day of freedom before she had to get back to work with press events and fittings for the Critics Choice Awards on the 4th January.

And despite her reputation, Rio had remained true to her word.

She’d kept her hands and her lips to herself during her party.

She even kept her tongue in her mouth whenever Agatha was mentioned and as drunk as she was she gave nothing away and only nodded and smiled when people mentioned her name to her.

The picture of her and Nicky sat hidden in her bathroom cabinet and her precious new necklace sat on her vanity.

But her mind, her heart, they were full of Agatha all the time. Full of the prospect of seeing her in three days, full of the idea that she might be able to hold her hand, if only secretly, and for a few stolen moments.

And maybe it was the start of the new year. Maybe it was that she’d rung it in surrounded by friends. But she felt hopeful for the first time in a while.

Chapter End Notes

I’m on holiday tomorrow for a week but I am halfway through the next chapter so depending on how my working day goes today I might get that out soon too or else it’ll be when I’m back!

Next up: two awards shows and some pining

Chapter 19: Golden Girl

Chapter Summary

Rio and Agatha orbit each other in public.

The real awards start.

Chapter Notes

Hi! Everyone asked for almost 17k words worth of pining right? Right?!

See the end of the chapter for more notes

“Rio!”

The cacophony of noise in the glittering ballroom born within the depths of a sweeping historic airplane hangar meant that Rio didn’t hear her name being called over and over.

She was instead in deep conversation with the man next to her, a very boring man with a thick moustache that reminded Rio of a sweaty walrus. Unfortunately for her, she’d been seated next to him for the last twenty minutes.

The walrus just so happened to be head of the studio that was spending millions to try to get her the Oscar.

Which meant that Rio had to keep her marine-themed jokes to a minimum.

“I really think you should reconsider this latest activism, you know. Got to be friends on both sides.”

“I’m not sure being gay really counts as activism,” Rio said with just a hint of amusement in her voice and a smile that widened when the moustache quivered with a shake of the man’s head.

“Don’t mistake me, I merely mean-…”

“Rio, my god.”

Rio felt a hand on the side of her head and one on her shoulder and a pair of lips pressed against her temple to be quickly replaced by a thumb brushing away the lipstick left there.

“Sorry,” Wanda whispered quietly as Rio turned to her with a grin, her hand finding the one still on her shoulder.

“Wanda, you know Nick Craine?”

Rio squeezed and released Wanda’s hand as the moustache with legs stood and pressed his bristly face into Wanda’s cheek.

Rio had to turn and sip her wine to hide her laugh.

“Pleasure as always, Wanda. I’ve been selfishly keeping poor Rio to myself. I’ll leave you ladies to it. But perhaps… before I go… a photo op, on your right.”

Rio turned just as Craine pointed to a photographer snapping his way through the crowds and she smiled as she stood to position herself next to one of the reasons she was getting so much attention this season.

He wrapped an arm around her and Rio had to fight hard not to recoil from the sweaty palm that hit her bare skin of her upper back.

She felt Wanda squeeze her arm as it rested across the broad back of the exec between them and she bit the inside of her cheek even as she grinned at the man memorialising the moment with his camera.

The moment was soon captured and Rio rolled her shoulders back in an attempt to shake off the lingering feeling of clamminess against her back as the head of the studio went off to schmooze more unwilling actors.

“Jesus, I always forget how-…”

But Rio was laughing already and turned to smack Wanda’s arm.

“Don’t. I spent twenty minutes with him.”

“Hmm, and where is your guard dog?”

“Oh Alice is off trying to talk a casting director into getting me into a Star Wars.”

Wanda rolled her eyes affectionately and Rio turned to take her glass back up, missing Wanda’s next question: “Who dressed you today?”

She missed it because across the room, far enough away that she could almost be a mirage, Rio saw Agatha for the first time since Boston.

There she stood sandwiched between two men in suits, looking far more beautiful than Rio remembered but a hand on her arm pulled her away from the vision before her and she raised her brows at a curious Wanda.

“Hey, too much wine already?”

“No, just…” Rio ran a hand through her hair then remembered she’d promised her hairstylist she wouldn’t do that. “What were you saying?”

“Who styled you? It’s good. Colour’s crazy good.”

Rio smiled and brushed down the satin of her midnight blue gown, “Jerome. Didn’t you use him last year for this?”

Wanda frowned a little in thought and Rio took the opportunity to turn back to glance at Agatha again.

Only she timed it wrong.

Agatha was laughing, a great big movie star laugh.

Her hand fell to the chest of the man beside her. And Rio saw two things at once: Ralph, and a huge diamond ring on her left ring finger.

“Hey,” Wanda nudged Rio again, following her line of sight to where Rio was still staring, “God she looks good.”

Rio could only hum in response, watching as Agatha dazzled across at whoever she and Ralph were talking to, her hand still on Ralph’s chest, her ring as bright as her smile.

She turned away and focused back in on Wanda who had taken a glass from a nearby tray.

“Think it’s hers? Or have you written your speech?”

Rio scoffed and made to touch her hair again but pulled her hand back when she remembered her promise from earlier. “Alice wrote down a few names but… it’s hers.”

“Sure as hell isn’t mine,” Wanda said with a wry smile.

“Oh so modest,” Rio teased, taking the opportunity to take another glance at the happily married couple across the room.

Agatha was glowing.

Maybe it was the wide grin across her features, maybe the shimmer of whatever body makeup someone had applied to her to make her literally glow, maybe it was that Rio had just missed her so much.

But she looked like magic.

“Stop staring, Rio. It’s not very cool.”

Rio smiled a little but just as she was about to turn back she saw Agatha’s gaze raise to meet her own.

The lights distorted, casting their star shine between them as Rio’s heart rate picked up and Agatha’s smile morphed from wide and bright to warm and genuine.

A hand on her arm turned her around again and the moment was gone. The lights were behaving once more and Rio was looking into Wanda’s soft features.

“She’s beautiful. And her husband is too.”

Rio pursed her lips a little but softened when Wanda squeezed her arm with a kind smile, “Come on. We should make the rounds before any marine mammals find us again.”

Rio scoffed and followed behind Wanda into the crowds and soon found that they were stopped by acquaintances and admirers and Rio had no choice but to forget Agatha and her husband and focus back in on being the woman everyone expected her to be tonight: a grateful nominee, a delighted actress.

And she played the role well.

Thoughts of Agatha dissolved by the time Rio was five minutes into a very boring discussion about the layout of the space around them and she began to fidget on the spot.

Her fingers curled around the soft satin of her dress and she’d just made eyes at Alice across the room in a “help me” way when she felt a hand on her hip.

A press of a body just against her back.

Warm and familiar, her lungs filled with the scent of Agatha as she pressed around her, arriving at her side with her arm still flung around her as if they hadn’t been apart for weeks.

As if Rio hadn’t been yearning all this time.

“Rio,” Agatha breathed out as she pressed their cheeks together in a not quite kiss, her hand curling tighter around Rio’s hip until she was bunching the fabric slightly in her hand.

And Rio turned into her, because how could she not.

She raised her hand without thinking and grazed the underside of Agatha’s jaw with her fingertips and watched as blue eyes flashed at her and then softened.

“Rio, you’re looking lovely.”

Ralph.

Agatha’s hold on her dropped and Rio turned to the third person in what would be her absolute nightmare threesome scenario.

Ralph’s jaw was tight which only made him look more handsome and Rio stretched her head up to allow for the man to kiss away the lingering feel of where her cheek had just touched Agatha’s.

“Hi, Ralph.”

She straightened herself out again, and had enough sense left to introduce the man who’d grabbed her whilst she’d been making the rounds with Wanda.

Wanda had left her with an apologetic smile and she’d been stuck ever since.

The man honed in on Agatha immediately, because of course he did. And Ralph received a cursory handshake before Agatha was drawn into a conversation and Rio was left standing on the outside with Ralph hovering by her shoulder.

Tom Ford’s Oud Wood filled her lungs as she turned to him and she forced a smile to her face.

“Good Christmas?”

“Oh, you know how it is,” Ralph said with a very fake smile. He wasn’t as good an actor as his wife. “Nicky gets most of the attention and then the day’s done.”

If the universe weren’t so cruel, Rio wouldn’t have felt two things at once: the visceral need to pummel this man into oblivion and the gentle brush of knuckles against her own.

Forcing a nod and a laugh she tried again, “Well, he is the kid. Any good Celtics merch?”

“No, I’ve decided we’re going to be a Bulls family. I got him a season ticket. Paid it off for the next ten years so we’ll always have something to do together.”

This, Rio knew, was a reaction to the Boston trip.

A retaliation.

Only the only person who would be truly impacted by this was Nicky and she felt her jaw tighten and the hand that held her wine glass flex, suddenly imagining the stem was Ralph’s thick neck.

“Honey,” came Agatha’s voice from beside her.

And Rio turned because she was honey. But Agatha’s gaze was up on Ralph.

“We should take our seats. They’ll be starting soon.”

Oh but Rio hadn’t missed this. This torture of seeing Agatha with Ralph, of everyone else seeing it too, and of Rio just being some actress Agatha had once gone to a ball game with.

The only thing that anchored her spiralling thoughts was that she’d got to Ralph.

Her ‘friendship’ with Agatha seemed to threaten him and she would freely admit that she liked to see him struggle.

Only it meant Nicky suffered and that would never sit well with her.

That was unforgivable.

From the corner of her eye she saw Ralph nod, “I’ll fetch us drinks.”

And they were alone again, with Agatha having masterfully dislodged the limpet of a man who’d suckered onto Rio earlier.

“Is he okay?”

She had seconds, maybe, just enough time to try and calm her fury.

“He’s still mad about Boston, but-…”

“No, Nicky.”

Agatha raised her brows briefly and then dropped her gaze from Rio, glancing around at where Ralph had disappeared to as the room began to swirl with people moving this way and that through the space seeking drinks and their seats.

“He’s fine.”

Time was against her so she couldn’t probe but she nodded and moved her gaze from Agatha’s perfectly defined jaw to her perfectly defined nose.

The makeup Agatha wore obscured the freckles Rio had once been close enough to count but Rio knew they were there. And that had to be enough.

“Are you?”

“Yes.”

“You look good,” Agatha said quietly, her knuckles brushing Rio’s again as Alice arrived on the little reunion, a bright smile in place.

“Agatha! Checking out the competition?”

And Rio dissolved back into her own mind again as Agatha and Alice made polite small talk, some of the intimacy in their relationship dissolved now since Agatha and Rio had gone rogue against their managers.

A pale hand was moving through the air, gesticulating with Agatha’s words and Rio zoned in on it, wondering why the left-handed Agatha was using her right whilst her left hung limply at her side.

She shifted to get a sight of it and saw what she’d seen from a distance earlier.

A wedding band. An engagement ring.

She’d never worn the latter in Rio’s presence before. At least, not when she’d been sober and not off her face in a Chicago bar bathroom.

“Rio,” Alice said suddenly, cutting through the noise. “We should sit.”

Rio ran a hand through her hair and Agatha reached to fix it, her right hand just grazing her jaw as she placed her hair back to how a professional had spent hours arranging it earlier.

Their eyes locked and Rio wanted to kiss her.

But Alice had taken her hand and she was pulled away, back to the role she was playing that night, and back to her seat at her studio’s table.

As Rio slipped into place with Alice beside her she focused in on the soft conversation around her, sliding further and further from yearning as she did.

She knew Agatha would be close by at the next table.

They were favourites to win, meaning they were as close to the stage as they could get. And let’s face it, their respective studios would have paid to make sure their actresses didn’t need to walk a mile to pick up their gongs.

The lighting faded, the music kicked up, and in the dimmer room, Rio turned her head just slightly to see if Agatha were there. She saw nothing, no sign of her, until there she was.

Leaning back into view from where she’d been blocked by Ralph.

Agatha turned and they locked eyes and Rio saw her nod, caught her wink, and fell in love all over again.

But then her hand moved, and the light caught her diamond and Rio’s dark eyes fell to it and Agatha noticed, pulling her hand below the table even as Rio turned back around to focus on the night again.

She knew then why Agatha had been using her right hand earlier. She’d been hiding her ring from her.

A loud-mouthed, trying-his-best comedian appeared on stage to raucous applause and Rio politely joined in, settling herself in for a long night whilst her stomach churned with the nausea triggered by Agatha being so close and Ralph being right there with her.

By the fifth category a lot of the room was restless, and most people were disappearing now for comfort breaks or more drinks at the bar.

But Rio remained seated, remained sober, the only thing keeping her from zoning out completely was the occasional sound of Agatha’s laughter at the next table.

By category seven, she felt a hand brush her shoulder and turned to see Agatha walking away.

She took her in then, a black Bardot top over tailored black pants and stilettos that had made her just an inch or so taller than Rio.

She looked effortlessly glamorous and Rio could see all eyes turning to her as she passed by.

Because Agatha Harkness was someone you looked at, looked twice at. She was someone who drew attention and made people feel weak at the knees.

So Rio knew she wasn’t alone as she stared.

But she was alone in her misery.

She turned back to tune in again, making sure her smile was up for when the camera got close and her posture was that other than ‘prawn’.

A waft of perfume told her Agatha was back in her seat and sure enough their category was about to be called.

The audience about them stilled, each member holding its breath for what was to be the first decider in the five-part tally of the most prestigious awards bodies culminating in the final Oscar.

Rio felt Alice’s hand slip to her thigh and she turned to shoot her a comforting smile and saw that her best friend looked more nervous than she’d ever seen before.

But names were being read out and she had no time for comforting as a camera swooped into her face and “Rio Vidal” was met with an eruption from her table and whoops and applause the room over.

And Rio turned to look at Agatha, seeing that she was looking up at the stage and was toying idly with her rings.

But Rio could only now see the angle of her jaw, the profile that she’d memorised long ago, long before they’d even met.

And her eyes, as she looked to them Agatha had turned to her as if she’d felt her gaze on her. And Rio hoped she had. She hoped she could pinpoint her in a crowded room, hoped of everyone’s admiring glances, she’d always look for Rio’s first.

The cameras began to move again and Rio had to look away, had to hold and pose for her closeup. But Agatha was in her periphery, her steady smile not the one she’d just been giving Rio.

And their faces were on the big screen.

Agatha was all Rio could see.

“And the Critics Choice Award for Best Actress goes to… Agatha Harkness for No Heaven Like This!”

And Rio turned to see the reaction happen live.

The din around her quieting to a murmur as Agatha stood from her seat and hands grasped her shoulders. Her husband kissed her cheek and Agatha kept her eyes on Rio.

And Rio beamed at her because she deserved it, because this award was always going to be hers.

She watched as Agatha released a breath, and then matched Rio’s smile and was suddenly turning, suddenly pulling from Ralph’s hold without acknowledging it and stepping up to the stage.

And Rio wished she could have been the one to properly congratulate her. To kiss her first. To squeeze her hand and feel a different ring on her finger.

She swooned, her body giving out as her mind was focused on the sight of Ralph’s hands on the woman who was not hers.

“My god,” Agatha was saying into the mic.

“This is… too much. My god.”

She laughed, a perfect, modest explosion of joy.

And Rio was guided back to her seat by gentle hands pulling her down where she’d been one of the last standing, watching the great Agatha Harkness accept her first proper award of the season.

“This category…”

The room erupted with cheers and Rio felt Alice squeeze her shoulders.

Agatha was beaming, so at ease in the spotlight and commanding the space as she held her head high and shook it, making her hair bounce and the glitter on her skin sparkle under the lights.

“Rio Vidal.”

Rio sucked in a breath as Agatha met her gaze from the stage and her face softened even for a second as she took a breath.

“My son’s hero.”

Rio felt Alice’s hold on her shoulders tighten and her stomach flip as Agatha turned from her gaze to throw out the names of other nominees:

“Sylvia, Isla, Wanda…”

“I’m so honoured to be here tonight with you all.”

But Rio didn’t hear the rest of the speech because her ears were ringing with Agatha’s words and she couldn’t focus on anything else.

Agatha didn't linger on the stage long. Too professional and experienced to hover and splutter out more thanks.

“She didn’t thank Ralph,” Alice whispered into Rio’s ear, squeezing her shoulders as Rio watched Agatha stride form the stage.

“Or Jen,” she added as Rio turned to her and saw her frown.

“Where is Jen?”

Alice didn’t have a chance to answer because bodies were moving again in the brief pause between categories and Rio felt the familiar arm of a friend around her neck, “Hero, huh?”

“Shut it.”

Wanda laughed and crouched down between Rio and Alice, nudging Alice’s knee playfully, “What did you offer in exchange for that little shoutout?”

“Oh, Rio’s first born. And half her next paycheck.”

“A baby and ten dollars?” Wanda asked with a smile, “Agatha’s cheap.”

Agatha didn’t return after that. And Rio was able to focus properly because of it.

She celebrated enthusiastically when her writers won for best original screenplay and even cheered loudly when a director she’d worked with before won his award.

The ceremony drew to a close with a fizzle, rather than a bang.

The comedian’s last, lame joke was lost as chairs were scraped and glasses emptied as people began to mingle again, congratulating or commiserating or commenting on the night’s events.

And this time as Rio made the rounds, or more accurately, people made the rounds to her, Alice remained loyally at her side.

“No luck on the Star Wars front,” she managed to whisper in between well-wishers.

“I didn’t want that anyway,” Rio corrected with a smirk, poking her friend in the side just as a producer came over to chat.

It took an hour for Rio to extricate herself from the crowd, another ten minutes to move with Alice to the queue for cars lining up to take the attendees home.

Rio shivered in the cold and Alice shrugged her jacket off to drape over her client, smiling a little at the dramatic way Rio tugged it tighter around her.

“Such an actress.”

Rio narrowed her eyes but said nothing, focused instead on the two people moving towards them.

Agatha was moving through the crowds like a queen returning triumphant from war. Everyone either moved out of her way or tried to stop her as she went.

But Rio saw that she was making a beeline for them and she couldn’t help but feel warmed more by that than the blazer currently wrapped around her.

“Is this where the losers stand?”

She rolled her eyes, refusing to give Agatha the satisfaction as she moved closer.

“Heroes, actually.”

Ralph scoffed but Rio ignored it and glanced at Agatha’s exposed arms, seeing the goosebumps that raised there.

If the last time Rio had slept with Agatha told her anything it was that where Rio ran typically warm, Agatha was always colder. Which meant she must be frozen.

“Here,” she offered quickly, shrugging Alice’s jacket off.

But Ralph had moved to block her and Rio saw Agatha disappear behind him to re-emerge with his suit jacket over her shoulders.

She looked away, Alice’s jacket back on, her jaw flexing slightly.

“Agatha,” Alice interjected quickly, her eyes darting between Rio and the woman she addressed, “Congratulations, really. If anyone else deserves it other than Rio, it’s you.”

“Thanks, Alice.”

Rio looked down at her feet, praying the car would show soon, or hit her, either way.

“We should move on,” Ralph said importantly, and Rio looked up to see he was looking at his phone in an attempt to look just as important as he’d tried to sound.

But her inspection of him was cut short by an arm that snaked below her borrowed blazer and a pair of lips against her cheek. Agatha’s hold was tight but brief and by the time Rio had registered it, she’d gone.

“You’re still into her, aren’t you?”

Rio raised her brows and felt her cheeks flush despite the cold night air, finding in Alice an understanding dawn.

“No. We’re friends.”

“I was watching you at the new year party. You kept pushing people away.”

“Can we talk about this in the car?”

Alice nodded and Rio looked down at her feet again, tugging the blazer over her shoulders closer around herself.

The car soon rolled around and interrupted the silence between the two best friends. Rio slipped in first and sighed into the leather as she waited for the questions to come.

“She’s married.”

“I know.”

“She’s not interested.”

Rio swallowed and looked away, “I know.”

“You haven’t been looking for a girlfriend. You’ve been pining.”

Rio looked down at her knees, “It’s not pining, Alice. It’s-…”

Alice sighed and reached for Rio’s hand, “It’s stupid is what it is.”

“Alice.”

“Look, I just don’t want to see you hurt and falling over yourself for Agatha Harkness...”

Rio pulled her hand away and petulantly shrugged Alice’s jacket off, passing it back to her without looking, “I’m fine, okay? We’re just friends. Focus on your own relationship.”

It was a little harsh maybe but Rio couldn’t help but push back at her friend, her friend who had spent most of her time recently talking about either Jen or Awards. Who once a day asked Rio how she was but never probed further.

“Rio.”

Rio kept her gaze out the window, her jaw flexing and unflexing as the streets of Santa Monica flew past.

“When did we get this way?”

All wind went out of her sails then. Rio deflated where she sat. She felt a hand on her arm and a hand on her cheek and turned to see Alice frowning at her, her dark eyes tracing over her own pained features.

“We don’t talk anymore.”

“Alice.”

“We don’t.”

Rio shook her head and bit down on her lip as Alice pulled her hand away from her cheek, and her gaze dropped too.

Alice had been her constant, even more than her parents, because Alice understood the industry. She knew the pressures and the demands and had been with Rio through it all.

And now she was keeping a huge part of herself hidden from Alice. A piece of her that would have to remain hidden until someone else made the decision for her that it was no longer a secret to keep.

The soft nature of Rio Vidal meant that for this she was sorry, for this she was sympathetic to whatever her best friend was feeling.

But her misery had hardened a piece of her that poked a madness inside that wanted to accuse Alice of not looking, of not paying attention, of not helping her through.

Only, giving in to the hardness in her meant opening a crack that could spill out Agatha’s secret too.

So she cautiously reached back out for Alice and took a deep breath before she whispered, “I like her. A lot. And you should have known that when I told you in my trailer all those months ago. I’ve spent time with her since and I still like her and I don’t think it’ll go away any time soon so I’m working through it. But I need you to be with me on this. Because it’s painful and heavy and the only thing I can do is to keep going and hope that you’ll be my friend on this. Properly. No telling Jen or announcing over drinks that I feel this way. Because I want her and I’ve not wanted anyone like this before and I just can’t…”

A lone tear slipped down her cheek and Rio closed her eyes as Alice reached to brush it away.

“Okay,” she said just as softly, “okay you have me. It’s not stupid, I’m sorry.”

Rio shook her head then and turned away from Alice, looking out the window to try to steady herself, feeling a little lighter than she had before.

“It’s as stupid as you trying to put me in outer space with a glowing sword.”

“I mean, she is kinda outta this world.”

“Shut up.”

Alice snickered and moved her blazer back over to cover Rio’s lap.

They were silent for a while. The kind of silence that’s comfortable and Rio relaxed into it.

“Are we using ‘like’ when we mean ‘love’, Rio?”

“Yes.”

“Okay.”

They sat quietly again until Alice spoke and Rio turned to her when she did.

“You should know that she contacted me over Christmas.”

“She did?”

“Mm. She said she needed a contact that Jen couldn’t get which I thought was weird at the time but I didn’t ask. I was in the middle of contract negotiations anyway so I was a little busy but she called and-…”

“Who did she want?”

“Well, she wanted Stark.”

“Tony Stark?”

“Yeah.”

“But she would easily be able to get that from Jen.”

“That’s what I’m saying. Anyway, we didn’t talk for long but she did ask me how you were. Which again I thought was-…”

“When was this?”

“I don’t know, day after Christmas, maybe? I was up in Jen’s old room trying to negotiate-…”

“Alice.”

“Right. Well she seemed concerned about you and I just said you were fine, with your parents, and I hadn’t really heard from you which wasn’t unusual.”

Rio nodded slowly, frowning a little as she dropped her gaze to the blazer covering her legs.

The day after Christmas had been the day after their last messages. The day after Agatha had stopped responding after Rio’s stupid joke.

“Did you have a fight?”

Rio looked up suddenly, frowning as she took Alice in. “No. I just… we hadn’t spoken much since Boston so maybe she was just curious.”

Alice only nodded and Rio looked back out the window again, toying with the end of her hair and wrapping it and rewrapping it in her fingers.

“Are you not seeing anyone else because-…?”

Because I’m waiting for Agatha to be ready. Because whenever I close my eyes I can feel her hands on me. Because I want only her.

“Because it’s not fair on anyone else when I’m so hung up on her.”

“Okay.”

They were silent again on the journey back to Rio’s place where Alice was crashing for the night.

Rio fell asleep faster than she thought she might but slept fitfully, unable to escape the pangs of yearning as she did.

By morning everything felt a little softer again and she had nothing to do except to shower and allow the next round of dress fittings to happen.

The Golden Globes was the big one. It was second maybe to the Oscars, though the upcoming SAG awards were important too. Everything seemed important at this point.

The atmosphere in the little Spanish house was quieter than usual but calmer than it had been for a while. Alice had opted to put her phone away whilst Rio was pressed and moulded into different options and Rio knew that her best friend was trying to make up for time lost.

It meant she had whatever coffee or juice she wanted before she even had to ask.

It meant that Alice was a little kinder than she might normally be about some of the dress options and it meant that by the time the day was done and Alice was leaving with the people hired to dress and beautify Rio, that the actress felt a little better again.

She showered off all her makeup and changed into soft pyjamas before heading down the stairs to return to her favourite position on the couch with a glass of red and an old movie she wouldn’t have to pay much attention to.

For the first time that day she picked her phone up and skimmed through the various texts and missed calls from people she liked and people she didn’t.

And there, at 9:37am, was a notification from Agatha. A missed call.

She stared at it then checked her WhatsApp to see if there were any messages. But the last one had been from Christmas Day where Agatha hadn’t text back.

It took her another ten minutes and a whole glass of wine to buck up the courage to call Agatha back.

But she did.

It rang and rang and Rio began to lose hope that Agatha would answer until she was pulling her phone from her ear and she heard her voice.

“Rio.”

“Hey. I’m sorry I missed your call.”

“It’s fine. I was just checking in.”

Rio frowned a little, gazing down at the rug beneath her feet. “Worried I’d taken my loss badly?”

“Something like that.”

Agatha sounded soft, sounded relaxed, and Rio wondered where she was in her house, what she was wearing, what she was doing.

“Are you there?”

“Yes. Sorry. Just-…”

“I’m sorry I didn’t text back at Christmas. The house was full and I didn’t want to be seen to be-…”

“It’s fine, Agatha. I pushed it and I should have been more sensible.”

“You weren’t wearing your necklace yesterday,” Agatha said after a brief pause.

“Which?”

“Very funny.”

“Did you want me to?”

There was silence for a second and then Agatha spoke again and this time her voice was even quieter, “It was good to see you.”

“You too.”

Rio began twirling her hair and heard movement on the other end of the line, and she again found herself wondering where Agatha was, what she was doing.

“It was a PR decision. To have Ralph there.”

“And was it a PR decision to not mention him in your speech?”

Rio heard Agatha release a soft breath and she closed her eyes, knowing how that breath would feel against her skin.

“I wasn’t really thinking about him in that moment.”

“Were you thinking about me?”

“Yes.”

“Have you thought any more about… about what we discussed?”

“Yes.”

“And?”

Rio shifted and thought she heard a chink of glass in the other end of the line.

“It’s not easy, Rio.”

“I know.”

“I need time.”

“I’m trying to give you it.”

“Trying?”

Rio released a slow breath and ran a hand through her hair, “I’m here for you. I’m giving you space and time and… I have to see you with him and it kills me that he won’t even give you his jacket until he sees me trying.”

“You know it’s just bravado. Nothing more.”

“But he can touch you and kiss you and I get, what? A shout out in a speech and a quick kiss on the cheek?”

“Rio.”

“I just… I miss you.”

It hurt to even say the words and hurt even more acutely when she heard Agatha draw in a sharp breath.

“Can I see you before Sunday?”

“I have ADR and fittings and-…” Agatha started softly.

“It’s fine. It’s fine.”

“I want to see you too.”

“Will Ralph be there Sunday?”

“Jen wants him to be.”

“What about what you want?”

“It’s just a night, Rio.”

“Which after party are you going to?”

“Whichever one you’re at.”

Rio smiled a little and rubbed her hand over her face, sitting in the warm glow of the comment for a second before she said, knowing fully that she was feasting now on crumbs:

“Can you try to push back on him coming? Just this once.”

“Okay.”

“Really?”

“Can’t wear two jackets all night, can I?”

Rio scoffed and settled back a little more on the couch, feeling slightly more relaxed now she knew Ralph wouldn’t be there.

“What are you wearing?”

“It’s silver. Sleeveless.”

“No, I meant now.”

“You can’t be serious?”

“I just want to picture you.”

Agatha sighed quietly and Rio thought she’d refuse but she spoke again and was softer once more. “I’m in a red sweater. I’m wearing these soft pants and I have thick socks on and my hair is up. I’m in the den and I’ve been drinking red wine and reading my book.”

“Are you under a blanket?”

“Yes.”

“The same one we sat under?”

There was a pause. “Yes.”

“Do you wish I were there?”

“Rio.”

Rio closed her eyes again and felt sick with it, with the image of Agatha there without her.

“I should go,” she said quietly, the pull was too strong, the yearning suddenly too much for her.

“Stay on. Just a little while. We don’t even have to talk about anything. Just… stay?”

And Rio took in a shaky breath and moved to lay down, tugging her hood up and over her head as she stared at the coffee table before her.

“Okay.”

She was silent for a while, listening intently to the soft noises of Agatha moving around on the other end and she wondered if she were simply trying to get comfortable or if she felt uncomfortable in the silence.

“Why did you call Alice for Stark’s number?”

The question must have taken Agatha by surprise because she didn’t answer for a while and Rio waited patiently in the quiet.

“I wanted to talk to him about a movie.”

“Couldn’t Jen help?”

“Jen doesn’t want me to do it.”

Rio nodded and chewed on her lip for a second, “Alice says you’re not on the best terms?”

“We’re okay now. It wasn’t great after Boston.”

“I’m sorry about that.”

“Don’t be. I reached out to tell you we were going because I wanted you there.”

“Then I’m glad I came.”

Rio plucked at the thread of a cushion.

“Can we talk now about you spending a whole day with my parents?”

“What about it?”

“My mom wants me to practise my Spanish because of you. Says you’re much better.”

“I usually am.”

“Funny. Why didn’t you call?”

“It was a spur of the moment thing. I just had to get out the house.”

“Why?”

“My life is complicated, Rio.”

“Tell me.”

She heard Agatha sigh. “My mother’s not an easy woman and Ralph can do no wrong in her eyes and Nicky… I just wanted to give him some space for a while and knew he’d be happier if he could see you.”

Rio plucked so hard at the thread it began to unravel the floral pattern.

“Plus we already had gifts for you so…” Agatha trailed off.

“I wish you’d called.”

“Next time.”

“Ralph told me he bought a season ticket for the Bulls.”

There was another silence then and Rio began wrapping the excess thread around her finger.

“Nicky still wears your jersey.”

Rio nodded and swallowed thickly, watching the pattern of the cushion dissolve further as she continued to pull at the thread.

“I’m sorry my being at the game with you meant that-…”

“It’s not your fault. Ralph is just petty. He’s pissed Nicky won’t go along with him. Thinks he’s too much of a mommy’s boy.”

“See? If anything were to happen there’s no way they could take him from you.”

The silence felt heavier then and Rio watched as she peeled away another petal with the thread in her fingers.

“You’re Nicky’s favourite and you’re also my mom’s favourite,” Rio said in an attempt to lighten the mood again.

Agatha laughed softly down the phone and she found herself smiling at the sound of it.

“I’ve missed that sound.”

“How did we get here?”

“You tried to kiss me when I was drunk in a bathroom and I’ve been hooked ever since.”

“You make it sound so dirty.”

“I’m pretty sure it was dirty. The bathroom, that is.”

“I should have kissed you in the pool.”

Rio’s stomach flipped at the memory. Agatha’s freckled skin, the light burn across her chest, Rio’s legs so cautiously wrapped around her waist in the warm water. The way Agatha had looked at her.

“Why didn’t you?”

“I wasn’t sure you wanted it.”

Rio blew out a heavy breath and rolled onto her back, “I’m sure I couldn’t have been more obvious.”

“You were barely touching me.”

“Because I thought if I pressed myself against you you’d press charges.”

Agatha scoffed, “Well I probably would have accidentally drowned us. But not for horror that you tried something.”

“From sheer desire?”

“Something like that.”

Rio hummed and they both went quiet again. Half the flower was gone.

“Do you think we could get away? Have that week together you mentioned?”

“When did I mention a week?”

“You said a day wouldn’t be enough, and then a week wouldn’t be either.”

“A week of just us?”

“Yes. I have time after February. Not a lot. Then I’m shooting from March onwards.”

Agatha hummed quietly, “I have some time.”

“Then could we?”

“Where would we go?”

“Anywhere. Everywhere. Wherever you wanted.”

“I want somewhere no one can get to us. Just you and me.”

Rio’s lips twitched a little and she dared push a little more, “Can we?”

“Okay. I’ll look into it.”

If this is what fireworks felt like then Rio couldn’t believe people weren’t shouting about them more often. Her body felt too warm suddenly and she was blushing beneath the hood she’d just pulled up for comfort.

“Imagine what we can do in a whole week.”

There was one petal left.

“I’m actually not planning on doing anything.”

“No?”

“Just you.”

Rio shivered despite how warm she felt and closed her eyes, “Don’t say things like that when I can’t-…”

“Jen, I’ll call you later.”

Agatha had hung up.

The flower was gone.

Rio blinked at her phone, stared at her home screen. And felt the clanging realisation that snippets of Agatha were all she’d ever get if Agatha didn’t leave her marriage.

Ralph must have appeared.

And far from what they’d just been discussing, if Ralph knew Agatha were talking late at night to Rio she suspected by now that he wouldn’t like it.

She dropped her phone to the side and pulled her hood tighter around her despite the heat and fell asleep on the couch that night, frustrated and self-pitying, a red thread tied tightly around her finger.

But waking came with the reminder that Agatha would be at the Globes alone. That she’d go to the same after party as Rio. And that she wanted a week with her.

She was still married. But she wanted Rio.

When Sunday rolled around Rio was practically vibrating with excitement to see Agatha that she’d forgotten she was nominated for a Golden Globe.

“Would you sit still,” Alice huffed and pulled Rio’s hand away from her glass of champagne as she tapped out the tune to ‘Go Your Own Way’ on the glass with her new sparkly nails.

“I’m excited.”

“You’re annoying.”

Rio laughed and rolled her eyes as the makeup artist moved in to start painting her lips.

“Shtup,” she muttered, trying not to move her lips as she narrowed her eyes at Alice through the mirror.

But the telIings off continued to come throughout the rest of the afternoon as Rio fidgeted where she sat or where she stood and Alice was hopeless to stop it whilst the glam squad were either laughing at the little arguments they kept having or else ignoring them as they made the movie star that now stood before them.

“I sometimes think it’s a miracle what can happen in just four hours with five experts.”

“Shut. Up.”

Rio twirled for the full effect, her green dress shimmering in the light with the delicate beading that patterned it.

“Where did you get that necklace?”

Alice looked curiously at the gem at the base of Rio’s throat as Rio wriggled her sparkly nails in her face to show them off.

“A gift.”

Rio was glad Alice dropped the subject and she went to kiss the glam squad goodbye, thanking them all for turning her into someone who looked like they belonged on a red carpet.

She’d be seeing them all again anyway when they appeared in the room at the Beverly Hills Hilton that they’d bought for the quick change between the ceremony and the after party.

But Alice was a stickler for timings and knew exactly when they should leave to get to the red carpet precisely when they meant to.

So Rio had barely the time to knock back her next glass of champagne before she was hurried from the cosy confines of her home to the waiting SUV to take them to the Hilton for the ceremony.

If Cannes were a big deal, then the Golden Globes was the ultimate deal.

Rio could barely breathe as she entered the carpet.

She couldn’t move for flashes all around her and her name being shouted and screamed from every which way.

She felt hot all over and worried she was blushing as she walked down the carpet.

But Alice was near and she kept grinning at her, kept offering a thumbs up whenever she could see her through the lights, and so she assumed she at least didn’t look ridiculous.

She found Wanda in the middle of a press gaggle and squeezed her side as she breezed by, interrupting the interview for barely a few seconds in favour of saying hi to her friend.

She swanned in and out of journalist’s bubbles to hit them with a sound bite, a quip, a smile or a wave.

But her eyes were constantly scanning for Agatha, for the woman who’d said she’d be there alone.

It was after Rio’s tenth interview along the carpet at the top of a set of inexplicable stairs that she had to walk gingerly up that she saw her.

The host of the E! network coverage was asking about her recent movie and she stuttered where she spoke as her eyes fell to Agatha, squeezing through the busy crowds with a scowling Jen just behind her.

Agatha hadn’t lied about her dress. It was strapless and structured, straight up and down and giving Agatha a column silhouette. It made her look timeless. Carved by angels.

And Rio could have stared for hours.

But the question still had to be answered and so she turned away.

“I-yeah, it was this gritty, earthy, crazy time. We had a lot of fun.”

The interview wrapped and Rio thanked the host with a smile and a quick handshake and she was walking down slowly, taking Alice’s hand to steady herself.

Only she hadn’t looked up to see who she was walking towards.

Whose arms were now out towards her to catch her on the last two steps.

Whose smile was brighter than the dress she wore and whose eyes were focused on Rio’s hungry gaze.

Behind her she heard a shout of, “And Agatha has arrived everyone! Agatha Harkness! Let’s see if we can get here to come up here.”

But the mingled noise of everything else and the arms that now encircled her cut off everything.

Agatha was pulling her into a tight squeeze and despite feeling like she was on fire and her ribs couldn’t take much more pressure she felt like she could breathe again.

“You’re with Jen,” Rio whispered as turned her head slightly, and felt the ghost of Agatha’s breath against her neck.

“You wore your necklace.”

Rio smiled and leant back, her hands falling to rest her fingertips on Agatha’s jaw.

She felt delirious, unable to form the words she so desperately wanted to say. But Agatha seemed to know she was struggling to act like a rational human being so she leant in and kissed her cheek sweetly, murmuring close to her ear, “I’ve missed you.”

She pulled away then and Rio felt dizzy as she stood and watched Agatha sweep by, Jen dutifully following her after gently squeezing Rio’s arm in greeting as she passed her by.

Rio took a slow breath in as Alice came to take her hand and pull her down.

It couldn’t have lasted as long as it felt. It must have been ten seconds at most. Because Alice wasn’t fussed by the pause in her schedule and Jen hadn’t looked like she was going to kill Rio.

But it had felt like a lifetime. It had felt like a whole other world just being held by Agatha in the most public arena in the world.

She was a movie star in love with a movie star and Rio Vidal was on top of the world.

The rest of the carpet flew by because Rio couldn’t think about much else.

She answered every question thrown her way as if it were her favourite question and she’d never been asked it before.

She smiled and waved and posed and laughed because for that night, for that one night, Agatha had left her husband for her.

But the Hilton ballroom wasn’t an easy place to find someone. So Rio didn’t see Agatha for a long time as it filled with people wilfully not going to their own seats and instead milling around by their friends or by people they thought more famous than them and therefore people they’d like to be friends with.

Rio sat with Wanda and a few of the team from A24 and made polite small talk with them in between gossiping with Wanda about what everyone was wearing, who already looked like they were going to win and who looked so nervous they might vomit.

The food on the tables went ignored and just as Rio was reaching for another glass of champagne - though she’d promised Alice she wouldn’t have any more - she saw Agatha through the crowds.

“Goddamn,” Wanda muttered quietly as her gaze fell to her as well.

“She’s beautiful,” Rio whispered softly, unsure why she suddenly felt shy under Agatha’s steady gaze, wondering why she felt like she should have tried to impress her more with her outfit, worn something more worthy of her.

It was too late to worry now because Agatha was arriving at their table and Wanda stood first to greet her.

“Agatha! You look incredible.”

“You too,” Agatha said with a small smile as she accepted the hug but kept her eyes on Rio who now stood just beside Wanda.

“I’ve just found my seat and you’re right beside it if you want me to show you?”

Rio blinked, having expected another hug or some small talk but she couldn’t deny Agatha anything and even the thirty seconds it would take to walk to her table beside Agatha would be the best thirty seconds of her year so far.

“Sure,” she breathed, turning to kiss Wanda’s cheek, “I’ll see you in the breaks?”

Wanda looked a little hurt but Rio touched her hand briefly and then turned to Agatha who’d already angled herself away, clearly not keen to hang around.

“She’s nice, you know,” Rio muttered as they made steps away from the red head. “You’d like her.”

“I don’t like many people.”

Agatha shot Rio a wry smile and Rio just rolled her eyes and boldly swung her hand forwards to hold Agatha’s. “We’re actors,” she whispered when Agatha made to pull away. “We touch. Look around.”

And sure enough the room was full of two types of people: the ones who were grinning and hugging and squeezing, and the ones who were smiling and shaking hands. But Agatha’s eyes took none of that in and she simply held Rio’s hand more firmly in her own, and led her in this way to their tables.

“You’re behind me?” Rio asked as she looked between the two place names with a raised brow.

“Of course not. You were over the other side. I moved you. Alice too.”

“You moved me?” Rio asked incredulously, fighting off the grin that threatened to split her face in two as Agatha sat down before her and still held her hand between them.

“Are you going to sit down?”

Rio laughed and sat slowly, watching as Agatha’s eyes fell to her necklace and then a few inches south before her gaze snapped up again.

“Subtle,” she said quietly, turning their hands over so she could link their fingers. She scooted her chair in closer.

“Rio,” Agatha warned softly but didn’t drop her hold.

“I’ve missed you. Allow me this.”

“We’ll be pounced on any second.”

“Then let me enjoy it for a second.”

Agatha smiled and dropped her gaze to their joined hands, rubbing her thumb back and forth slowly and giving Rio time to take her in again.

Her hair was loose and draped over one shoulder and her lipstick was ruby red and Rio wanted it painted all over her body. But Agatha was looking up again and for the briefest moment she looked sad as she took Rio in.

“Have you… been seeing anyone?”

But Rio’s response was lost as Agatha’s prediction came true. They were pounced on.

Agatha sprang to her feet as Jen arrived with a group of important looking men in ill-fitting suits and Rio jumped up too, because everyone was just as keen to speak to her as they were to Agatha.

Only Rio now had a permanent support system in place for this type of barrage.

Agatha had placed her hand on the small of Rio’s back and if the fact that it had been there for over five minutes now meant anything it meant that she wasn’t keen on removing it any time soon.

But heaven could only hold on so long and soon the lights were flashing and there were calls from around the room for everyone to take their seats.

Agatha’s hand moved to Rio’s from her back and she squeezed it gently, making Rio turn to her with a lazily smile, “What?”

“Good luck,” Agatha grinned, her free hand moving to brush the jewel of Rio’s necklace, “I think you’ll need it.”

Rio narrowed her eyes but realised something she hadn’t noticed before. She turned their hands over and looked down at Agatha’s in her own, seeing it completely empty of rings.

Agatha hummed quietly and gently dropped Rio’s hand, “I wanted to be free tonight.”

They locked eyes and Rio could only nod once, only swallow down the desire to take Agatha’s hand and run with her from this stuffy, stifling ballroom. Because Hollywood didn’t matter when she had Agatha for the night.

“Rio,” Alice hissed urgently, tugging at her arm where she’d just arrived by her side to take her place. “No more gossiping.”

Rio barely blinked but sat slowly, endlessly grateful that Agatha had moved her around so she could be just across the aisle from her, within an arm’s length if she were to lean around and want to touch her. And of course she wanted to reach across and touch her.

Rio’s body was set to vibrate again because she could hear Agatha’s voice and hear her laugh and when they both turned to look up to the stage she always caught her eye, sometimes caught a wink.

It felt like the secret wasn’t so scary or hard anymore. Like it was instead glamorous and sexy.

Like she could flirt and touch and not be caught because everyone else was doing it.

Hell, one of the producers on her table was already so smashed he was falling asleep into his tux.

In the grand tradition of the Globes, the opening monologue started out with a roasting of all the guests.

Alice had prepared Rio for it. She’d made her practice her smiles and ‘I’m vaguely insulted by that but it’s totally true’ faces. It had been a humiliating hour.

The roast started off slow, getting a few titters from the audience and then the jabs began to pick up in their venom and Rio could feel the tension in the room rising.

“And over here we have Agatha Harkness!! Yes, yes,” the host agreed, clapping his hands with the eruption from the room, “one of the greats. One of the greats. Agatha is here tonight with her movie: No Heaven Like This, a light hearted romp about a mother losing her child. But we’re not hear to laugh at dead children, obviously. Let’s talk about how Agatha’s real life child actually looks like another actress in the room, Rio Vidal!”

Rio was biting on her tongue, desperate to turn and see how Agatha was taking this.

She got a few cheers from the crowd and felt Alice’s foot gently nudge her own below the table.

“Ironic, really, considering how Rio is of course a beautiful Latina woman but actually she just looks like a little white boy whose grandmother practically funded the modern Republican Party.”

There was a great intake of breath about the room and some low “oohs” rather than laughs at this and Rio managed to smile softly, but refused to give any more.

When the comedian had moved on after an “alright, alright”, Rio turned to Agatha across the aisle and nudged her shoulder. Agatha turned slightly and shot her a small smile, and Rio knew she’d never give her more than that when cameras were around but she wanted her to know she was checking on her all the same.

By the time of the first break, Rio was fidgeting again, desperate to get to Agatha. But she didn’t even have a chance because Agatha was on her instead.

She’d stood from her chair and was leaning around Rio under the pretence of stealing a champagne bottle from the table and whispered as she did: “Jen’s furious. Hates it when people are reminded who my mother is.”

Rio could only nod, only reach back for the hand that still rested on her shoulder as Agatha straightened up and Jen appeared by Rio’s side.

“Goddamn you, Vidal. Next time you want to go to a basketball game-…”

“Hey.”

Rio felt Agatha squeeze her shoulder, “We agreed it was done.”

Alice cleared her throat then and went to stand by Jen, wrapping an arm around her waist. “Not tonight, babe.”

Jen pursed her lips and Rio smiled widely up at her, unable to do anything but when Agatha was so gloriously standing above her like a protective partner.

“Got you a few more lesbian fans, Jennifer.”

Jen just rolled her eyes and placed her hands on Alice’s arm. “She had those already.”

Rio scoffed and felt Agatha’s hand twitch where she held it gently against her shoulder, her fingers tickling along her skin until they came into contact with the necklace at the crook of her neck and Rio had to fight the blush at such an intimate touch that went unnoticed by Jen and Alice as they had turned into one another and started to talk about category position (second to last of the night).

Rio turned her head properly then, shifting in her seat to look up at Agatha with raised brows, “Yes?”

“Nothing,” Agatha smiled a little and pulled away, actually stealing the champagne as she took her seat again.

Rio narrowed her eyes at her and couldn’t help but think she’d been trying to get a reaction from her and she’d managed it, which was infuriating.

The ceremony went on and Rio’s giddiness never died down.

When people came to stop by during ad breaks she found that Agatha was always a little closer to her even if she weren’t in the conversation.

She managed to find a way to brush past or to squeeze her and Rio found herself doing the same every opportunity she got.

She’d stopped drinking now for fear she’d get too drunk and simply sit on top of Agatha and give everyone a real show. Besides, her category was up next and she couldn’t be caught looking drunk whilst trying to give a gracious loser face.

She sat up a little straighter, felt Alice touch her back, saw the grins on everyone’s faces along the table, and then tried to focus in on the presenter.

The names of the nominees were read out just as they had been three nights ago.

Agatha first.

The other three: Sylvia, Isla, Jessica this time, and Wanda next.

Then Rio.

And Rio nodded and grinned when her face filled the big screen and she felt another gentle touch from Alice on her back.

She wondered if Agatha might mention her first again. If without Ralph there, she’d feel the need to thank him, if she might even say she loved him.

But then there were other possibilities: Agatha might even stand up and kiss her. She might even announce to the room and to the millions watching at home that she was leaving Ralph and running away with Rio.

Perhaps she’d propose.

But Rio was shaken from her daydream. Literally.

Alice was shaking her and other hands were on her, grabbing her arms and tugging her waist.

And with wide, frightened eyes, Rio looked around frantically for the source of the panic, for the thing that everyone was trying to pull her from, until she saw Agatha and the sea parted and the hands moved and the only person she felt was Agatha as she held her face and Agatha as she kissed her cheek and Agatha as she spoke into her ear: “You need to get up there, Rio, now.”

Rio’s whole body stiffened where she’d just been holding Agatha’s arms and she felt the sea of people move with her, Agatha turning her to push her by the waist up to the stage.

It took a producer from Agatha’s table to offer his arm out to her to get her to actually walk up the stairs to the microphone and even when there she accepted the award with a horrified expression on her face, her mind trying to catch up with what had just happened to her.

Someone kissed her cheek and turned her to the mic as she clutched her award and for a second Rio just stared at the mass of expectant faces.

She blinked until she looked down at the real life Golden Globe in her hand and something about the weight of it, about the cool metal against her warm palms shocked her into action.

“Holy shit,” she muttered unthinkingly, only looking up when people started to laugh.

“I-I… I feel like I just spaced out for a second and-…”

But this wasn’t a good start to a speech. It wasn’t eloquent or commanding like Agatha’s had been only a few days ago.

She swallowed and looked out to where she’d come from and saw Alice standing and clutching her heart and Agatha just along from her, also standing, beaming up at her and nodding as if to get her to continue.

“I’m just a kid from Delaware who fell in love with movies at a really young age. I used to dream of playing for a living, of putting on different clothes and… and being free.”

Her voice sounded alien to her. It sounded too high pitched. Her words were coming out too fast.

She bit her lip and glanced down at the Globe in her hands, before she looked towards Agatha again. She was still standing, still watching her, still smiling.

“Firstly, I want to thank the person I consider to be the best actress of our generation, of anyone’s generation, Agatha Harkness.”

There was a smattering of applause and Rio smiled as Agatha rolled her eyes at her.

She felt more like herself now. Her breathing was evening out slowly. Her smile softening to be less than manic. Her words a little less shrill.

“My fellow nominees, Wanda, Isla, Jessica, Sylvia.”

More applause.

“The HFPA. My team, my Alice, my cast and crew, my incredible mom and dad. I’m so grateful to you all.”

She smiled a little wider this time and made sure to look everywhere but at Agatha, not wanting to give herself away.

Her brain had slowed down properly and she could form coherent thoughts now.

“And this is dedicated to any little kid, any person, who dreams of one day being free. Thank you. Te veo.”

Someone led Rio off the stage and Rio felt robotic as she followed them. She felt like she’d just lied to everyone or that she’d somehow misunderstood why everyone had ushered her up there.

But the press backstage was very real.

And Rio hadn’t thought that it would be even remotely a possibility that she’d be here, that she’d be clutching a Golden Globe.

But here she was.

And here they were.

And then there was Alice, Alice who’d clearly fought her way backstage to be there. She stood at the sides and smiled at her through tears she’d clearly been fighting since Rio’s name was announced.

The room was too loud to think. Too loud to allow Rio to process her emotions.

So she powered through, answering everything as best she possibly could.

Running on the fumes of disbelief, she made her way from the stage after twenty minutes of intense questions and found Alice still waiting, still almost crying.

“Holy shit,” they said in tandem and dissolved into fits of laughter as they were escorted from the little press holding room.

Rio was met from all sides by more press and more attendees and she could barely think for the next hour as she was moved and guided and photographed and interviewed.

There was pre-Golden Globe and post.

And Rio liked post very much.

Everyone seemed to be a little nicer to her, everyone was a little happier to see her. And she was a famous actress: people were always happy to see her.

Funnelled through to the little room where she was to get her Globe engraved, Rio finally had a second to breathe.

Only breathing in a very busy room where cameras were still pointed at you from every angle wasn’t exactly the most relaxing experience of her life.

More hands had never touched her before, more lips had never honed in on her cheek, and more praise had never been thrown her way before. But none of them came from the person she wanted to see the most.

It took Alice and a very helpful security guard to extract Rio from the venue almost two hours after she’d won.

They ran through the lobby of the hotel high on their success and drunk on their incredulity.

Alice had arranged for Rio’s change of clothes to be setup in a small room in the hotel which was a miracle because Rio needed to take her shoes off just as much as she needed a moment’s peace and a very large glass of wine.

“We did it kid,” Alice was saying as Rio huffed a laugh and fell backwards onto the bed.

The makeup artist knelt beside her and Rio closed her eyes as she allowed her to paint her lips a slightly different shade of red to the one before.

She was silent for a while as she allowed this.

“Can we stop now? No more awards? No more parties?”

“You love a party.”

“I love not having sore feet.”

Alice laughed as the champagne popped and Rio leant up to begin wrestling her shoes off of her feet.

Her stylist moved quickly over to help and Rio wasn’t sure whether it was to ensure she got her aching feet free faster or it was simply because he was worried she was being too aggressive with the delicate straps.

“I gave Jen our room number.”

Rio almost fell from the bed as she struggled with the clasp of her right shoe. The kind hands of her stylist helped her remain steady.

“Alice.”

“Relax. They’re going where we’re going. I just thought it would be easier. Besides, Ralph isn’t here and I thought maybe you’d want to see her a bit.”

Rio flopped back onto the bed and flung her arm over her eyes. Her feet were now free. Someone squeezed her calf.

Alice was beside her, leaning over her, whispering:

“Do you want to see her?”

“Of course.”

“Then stop complaining.”

Rio laughed a little, unable to tell Alice that she wanted to see Agatha alone because then maybe she’d get at least a little above the dress action away from prying eyes. But she supposed seeing Agatha in a room of just the four of them and the hard-working artists was as much as she could hope for.

“Rio?”

“Mm?”

“That Oscar’s yours, baby.”

Rio laughed properly this time, her stomach actually hurting from it by the time she got her breath back.

The room cheered for her.

There was a knock just as Rio’s breathing was evening out again and she sat up on her elbows suddenly, watching with wide eyes as Alice went to open it, holding a glass of champagne in one hand.

Jen stepped in first and looked less than pleased and Agatha stepped in right after, looking a little smug.

And looking absolutely earth-shatteringly gorgeous.

She wore a short white dress with sheer panels over her thighs and upper chest and Rio wasn’t sure she suddenly wasn’t drooling.

Her mouth felt dry and her cheeks felt hot and she couldn’t stop staring.

“Agatha gave you that win, you know.”

“Jen,” Agatha said firmly as she moved to lean back against the wall by the door, intentionally or not now giving Rio a full view of her look for the after party.

Rio’s gaze fell to toned thighs that had been around her waist, around her head, and she felt dizzy with desire.

“The HFPA have no interest in-…”

“HFPA, HPV, whatever. I know your comments and your field trip helped.”

Rio raised her eyes again and caught Agatha looking her over. She looked just as hungry as Rio felt.

She sat up properly then, some of the thoughts now able to return to her brain now she’d got just a semblance of satisfaction knowing Agatha wanted her too, and raised her brows at Jen, “Maybe I am just appreciated as a good actress.”

Agatha smirked at her and Rio stuck her tongue in her cheek.

“Or maybe they were just awarding her excellent management,” Alice smiled as she forced champagne into Jen’s hand.

“Maybe you both just annoyed them into it.”

“Listen, if I could annoy people into things I’d be on a beach somewhere right now with a pretty girl on my sun lounger.”

“Is that right?” Agatha asked with raised brows and a tight jaw.
