Rio only grinned and flopped onto her back. Not looking at Agatha was safer. She could pretend she wasn’t what had caused the dull ache between her thighs.

“The prettiest girl.”

Agatha just hummed from her position still against the wall and Rio laughed quietly, flinging her arm over her eyes.

“Anyway, we should get going Agatha.”

“Stay for a drink?” Rio asked suddenly, sitting up straight and looking only at Agatha.

Her pillar-box red lipstick juxtaposed so brilliantly with the white of her dress. So much so that she looked like a chic French bride, or the top new fantasy of Rio Vidal on cold, lonely nights.

“Maybe one,” Agatha said, smiling down at Rio from where she still stood. She reached out and accepted the glass Alice was now passing to her. “A toast to the winner of the evening.”

“I’m not toasting to that,” Jen said with a deep frown, now Alice wasn’t wrapped around her she’d wrapped her own arm around her waist. “It’s like putting bad juju on the next awards and I’m not risking it.”

“BAFTA will go Agatha’s way,” Alice said with a smile.

“Because they’re all old and posh?” Rio shot Agatha a grin and found that Agatha shot her such a teasingly furious look that she had to not look again.

She flopped back onto her back.

Someone tutted nearby and Rio was pulled to her feet and before she could protest she was whisked from the room to the bathroom to change.

She was malleable, biddable, to the hands removing her dress for her and placing her new one over her head and shoulders. She was given a sip of champagne through a straw after her new dress was put on and she stared at the new version of herself in the mirror.

She’d been in a softer green before and now she was in a fierce red.

She stepped from the bathroom, fully hoping Agatha’s tongue would fall out of her mouth at the sight of her. But it was just Alice. And her tongue remained resolutely inside her mouth.

“Damn, Vidal. A winner!”

“Where did they go?”

“They just stopped by, couldn’t hang out forever.”

“Right,” Rio said with a smile that didn’t quite meet her eyes.

Alice chewed on her lip and turned away to grab her purse from the side.

“Let’s go and greet your admiring public.”

Rio rolled her eyes but turned to give the team one last goodbye and several hugs and kisses and then followed Alice down the hall and to Netflix’s big after party bash.

The requisite social posts were taken along the way.

“Your socials have been blowing up, by the way. Everyone loved the speech. And lots of chat online about Agatha coming to help you up the stage.”

“She didn’t help me up.”

“She woke you up, more like. You looked like you’d zoned out completely.”

“I was in shock. It was shocking.”

“Not to me. I knew this would happen. You’re getting that damn Oscar.”

Rio just laughed because how could she tell her best friend that she was far was bothered about getting the Oscar than she was about getting the girl.

A short trip to another red carpet later and Rio found herself back in a huge room full of glamorous people and a hell of a lot of noise.

She was lost for a while in the madness of it. She shook more hands than she could count and kissed more cheeks than she’d have liked.

And then, across the room, she saw Agatha again.

Resplendent in her white dress.

She was running her hand through her mane of wild hair, laughing politely at whatever the woman with her was saying.

And then it happened.

She turned her way.

The softness of Agatha’s gaze had disappeared and now she was practically eye-fucking her across the room.

And Rio decided not to just stare anymore. She appreciated and let Agatha know she was doing so.

Instead of the unbidden fuzziness that had settled in her chest all night, something settled lower, something hungrier, fiercer, that had appeared earlier when she’d first seen Agatha after her win. Something that made Rio want to storm across the room and show everyone exactly who Agatha belonged to.

Unable to do it, she settled for letting Agatha know what she wanted from across the room.

She moved her hand slowly up to her necklace, toying with the emerald with her fingers as she traced her tongue across her lower lip and trailed her eyes slowly over Agatha’s body.

She caught a flash of something unbidden even in the distance between them - bright blue eyes that looked suddenly dangerous and Rio felt like willing prey, exposing herself to her hunter for a quicker, but no less clean, kill.

“Rio,” Wanda’s voice brought her back to the conversation and she turned her head to smile absently, taking a sip of her wine to try to cool her racing mind.

She could feel Agatha’s gaze on her.

“You realise I’ll have to act alongside three Oscar winners?”

“What? Three?”

“When you win, obviously.”

Rio rolled her eyes, “We’re a long way away from that. Besides, nominations aren’t even out yet.”

“And there’s no way you won’t get a nom. You know that. Modesty doesn’t suit you.”

Rio grinned into her glass, “Everything suits me.”

“Don’t bring this attitude to set.”

“It’s not an attitude. It’s a personality.”

Wanda rolled her eyes and nudged their glasses together with a smirk, “Well, cheers to my arrogant wife and her spectacular win.”

Rio just laughed and took a sip of her wine, “Better up your game or I’ll act rings around you.”

“Can’t believe you get as many women as you do.”

Rio shrugged and her gaze drifted back across the room, her smile fading and softening when she saw Agatha watching her still, only half listening to whatever the people surrounding her were saying.

She quirked her brow slightly, wondering if she’d ever be able to just walk across a crowded room and kiss her.

“You know,” Wanda said in a much quieter voice, “I’ve actually been meaning to talk to you about this wife thing.”

“Mm?”

“I think it would be good for us to date.”

Rio choked on her wine. Properly. Ungracefully.

She spluttered and coughed as she looked back to Wanda with wide eyes, “Pardon me?”

“Not for real, obviously. But…” and Wanda stepped closer even as Rio was patting her own chest and trying to swallow down the jagged edges in her throat. “Even being friendly with Agatha has propelled you forwards so us being seen as a power couple?”

“Wanda,” Rio started with a frown, her hand at the base of her throat and the necklace against the heel of her hand. Agatha.

“I’m not friendly with Agatha for PR.”

“I know,” Wanda smiled softly and Rio sighed, seeing a slight shyness in her gaze.

“Can’t we just be friends? Without the PR?”

“It’s just a suggestion,” Wanda said with a shrug, now avoiding Rio’s eyes.

Rio moved in and placed a firm kiss to her cheek, smiling warmly when Wanda turned to look at her again. “I always knew you wanted to get in my pants.”

“Oh fuck off.”

Rio’s smile grew as she pulled away and laughed, “Besides, you’d have to get past Alice first and I made her promise years ago she’d never make me do PR like that.”

“She’d give in for me.”

“Now who’s arrogant?”

“Hey,” Rio raised her brows and turned at the sound of the familiar voice and her smile only grew as she looked it’s the expectant eyes of her best friend.

“Hey.”

“Agatha said you needed me?”

“Oh,” Rio uttered quietly, glancing up to see that Agatha was where she had been earlier but now was definitely not looking her way. “She did?”

“Just grabbed me on my way past.”

Rio hummed quietly and turned her attention back to Alice, “Not sure why she’d do that.” She knew exactly why.

“Wanda, wanna ask Alice your question?”

“Yes,” Wanda said so confidently that Rio looked up in surprise. “Alice, have you placed a bet on Rio winning?”

Rio pursed her lips to fight her smirk and Wanda shot her a warning look that made Rio have to bite her tongue to not laugh at.

But Alice was answering and Rio took the opportunity again to check on Agatha.

She caught her looking. But only for a second and then she was looking away and Rio felt a pang of longing run through her before she felt an arm around her shoulders and she turned to Alice.

“I can’t comment on my client’s future awards, Maximoff. Let’s just focus on this one.”

Rio scoffed and draped her arm around Alice too, wondering when Agatha had decided to send her over. Was it when Wanda made her choke? When she made her laugh? When she moved in closer? When she kissed her cheek?

“Yeah, yeah, so long as you don’t forget me when you’re at the top.”

“I’m always at the top.”

“Not from what I’ve heard.”

Rio narrowed her eyes at Wanda and laughed until the redhead moved closer to kiss her cheek and whisper, “think about it.”

In alternative universe, Rio thought as she gazed into soft green eyes, Wanda would have been the better option to fall for. She was kind and funny and most importantly: not married.

But even as her hands raised to touch Rio’s cheek as she moved away Rio knew she wouldn’t ever feel for Wanda, could never feel for Wanda, the way she felt for Agatha.

Her touch didn’t set her on fire.

“No,” she promised with a gentle smile that only made Wanda roll her eyes as she went to kiss Alice’s cheek too.

“I’ll catch you both later. Don’t cause havoc.”

Alice laughed as she turned fully to Rio and gripped her arms, “So. Did you actually want me?”

“No. Agatha must have meant something else.”

Alice narrowed her eyes suspiciously but nodded and released Rio, “Fine. But let’s go schmooze. Everyone’s been asking where you are. And avoiding interrupting you and Wanda because you look so cosy.”

Rio raised her brows at this assessment and allowed herself to be pulled in the direction of some faces she vaguely recognised.

“Cosy?”

“Yeah.”

“Like…”

“Like you’re so invested in her you have no interest in anyone else.”

Rio glanced over her shoulder and saw Agatha watching her as Alice continued to drive them across the room.

If Alice thought Rio looked totally focused on Wanda and no one else then she couldn’t even imagine what Agatha thought about it.

A clammy hand was suddenly in hers though and Rio was grinning her way through more introductions and small talk.

It felt good to be this important all of a sudden. But being important to people whose names she’d forget by tomorrow evening wasn’t exactly the same as being important to the woman who’d disappeared through the crowds.

Still, the evening dragged on and Rio was soon in a small huddle of fellow actresses, draped over a chair with her Globe back in her hand - having let it be passed around like a joint at a frat party.

“It just doesn’t suit you,” Carol Danvers said with a smile that let Rio know she was trying to tease her.

“Looks so out of place in your hands.”

“Perhaps it’ll look better on my shelf,” Rio suggested with a smirk.

“Unsure,” Carol smiled.

“Perhaps you can put it in your bedroom,” a voice from behind Carol said and Rio looked up to see Agatha there. “Something sexy about that.”

Rio swallowed and motioned for Agatha to sit beside her but Agatha drew up a chair beside Carol instead and smiled across at Rio, as she frowned at her, getting a little sloppy with all the champagne she’d been plied with.

“I haven’t seen you all night,” Carol turned to Agatha and stole her completely from Rio and Rio couldn’t help the huff of jealousy as she watched it happen.

She kept her eyes on the two of them for a while, seeing Agatha shine her light on someone who wasn’t her.

But Jessica was close by and had taken it upon herself to begin bothering Rio about what she might wear to the Oscars and so Rio had no choice but to focus on her instead.

She’d finished another glass of wine by the time Agatha moved over and found that she sat closer to her than she expected. Rio’s arm had been draped over the back of the seat and Agatha squeezed in beside her, her side almost touching Rio’s front and her hand very much touching her thigh.

It felt so natural that Agatha had just sat there that Rio’s brain didn’t even short-circuit. She simply continued her conversation across her with Jessica as if Agatha had never sat there.

But Agatha’s fingers were idly toying with her dress, hidden from view as they squeezed in between them, and her head had turned to Rio and soon the pull of her gaze was too much to ignore and she turned just an inch to look at her.

“Hey.”

Agatha removed her hand.

“Sounds like you’re planning an Oscars outfit for a winner.”

Rio moved her heavy Globe into the air and raised her brows, “Do I look like not a winner?”

“You look like you got lucky.”

Blue eyes dipped to the green gem sitting against the base of Rio’s throat and Rio smiled a little at the implication. “Oh you do think you had something to do with this. It’s not just Jen.”

Agatha smiled serenely and Rio narrowed her eyes.

“Hey,” Jessica said, nudging Rio back into the conversation so she looked up at her again.

“I’m just going to try and find Isla. She was cornered somewhere by some exec.”

Rio waved goodbye and turned back to Agatha who’d not even blinked as their fellow actress left.

“Comfortable being close, huh?”

“Well someone else was earlier. I’m just following her lead.”

Rio raised her brows and watched as Agatha turned from her again, brushing down her dress.

“Wanda?” Rio asked curiously, barely above a whisper.

But Agatha didn’t respond and Rio could only smile, because she knew Agatha so well at this point that she didn’t need to say anything.

She shifted an inch closer and dropped her voice, “Who knew you were so territorial?”

“Didn’t you ask me not to bring my husband?”

“That isn’t the same.”

Rio rolled her eyes but Agatha was smiling at her so she couldn’t bring herself to argue the point.

“You look incredible, by the way.”

Agatha shifted, imperceptibly at first, and then so that her body was more angled to Rio and Rio realised why in an instant. Her gaze fell and she realised that Agatha was showing off for her.

She’d crossed one leg over the other and had pushed her chest out briefly and Rio took it all in. She luxuriated in the view. The soft fabric of Agatha’s white dress doing things to her she couldn’t even name, couldn’t even understand.

“You’re staring.”

“Can you blame me?”

“You know,” Agatha said quietly as she glanced around and Rio continued to stare, wondering now if anyone would notice if she simply reached out to feel the sheer fabric across Agatha’s upper thighs.

“Ever since you got up on that stage, all I’ve been able to think about is you, your award beside you, on your knees for me.”

Rio choked on nothing, and a few people nearby glanced around.

She recovered quickly but blushed a hot pink and cleared her throat, unable now to look anywhere near Agatha, let alone match her teasing gaze.

“What?”

“Something incredibly sexy about having the most powerful person in the room on their knees for you.”

“I-…” Rio’s eyes must be wide, must be comically so, and she looked all around them to check this wasn’t a prank of some kind or in the very least they weren’t being overheard.

“Agatha, you know I’d be on my knees for you right now if I could.”

Agatha hummed quietly and her hand moved just the two inches it needed to until she could get a hold of the hem of Rio’s red dress.

“Would you?”

“Yes.”

Rio looked up then, finally daring to now she had a slight hold on her breathing. Her arm across the back of the couch flexed slightly and she shifted just slightly closer and moved her trophy cautiously into Agatha’s lap and held it there, hoping she’d understand she’d give her anything.

The moment lasted longer than it should have and Rio soon found herself silently begging for Agatha to just kiss her, to just do something that would cure the ache in her.

But she didn’t. Her fingers remained gently curled around the hem of her dress and for now Rio had to settle for being close, being allowed at least this.

“Rio! Baby!”

Rio turned with a practiced smile that faded when she saw the person walking towards them, “Hey.”

“God, I only narrowly escaped-…” but Wanda trailed off as she sat on Rio’s other side and leant over to see Agatha there.

“Agatha, hi. I haven’t seen you all night.”

“Wanda,” Agatha said with so little warmth that Rio started to mentally kick her. She pulled back a little and focused in on Wanda who looked slightly off kilter.

It always took Rio a second to remember that Agatha was softer for her and not for anyone else.

“Who did you escape?”

“That creepy guy form Paramount. Always stands too close.”

Rio hummed and pursed her lips, looking behind Wanda to check she hadn’t been followed by said creep.

But a movement beside her caught her attention back as Agatha leant around to drape her arm over Rio and rest her wrist on Wanda’s leg.

Rio stared at it, and Wanda looked down too, momentarily paralysed by Agatha’s touch.

Agatha’s left hand found its way to the back of Rio’s neck, below her hair, and what felt like her ring finger slipped below the chain of her necklace as if to anchor herself there.

It felt surreal, as if Rio were imagining the delicate touch, but Wanda’s face must have looked as surprised as her own so she knew it were happening.

If Rio turned her head, if she leant in just an inch, she could kiss Agatha’s cheek, or swipe her tongue along the angle of her jaw, or nuzzle into her hair.

But she did none of those things.

“Tell me,” Agatha began to say.

And then Wanda’s hand was on her knee and Rio didn’t know if it was intentional or whether Wanda were just drunk and affectionate. But she thought it would be out of character for Wanda to try to challenge Agatha.

Wanda leant in too.

Agatha’s fingers flexed against the back of her neck but she made no other movement to suggest she’d even noticed Wanda’s hand now against Rio’s skin and instead continued her line of questioning.

“You’re still with UTA?”

Wanda nodded and said, “Yeah. Have had the same agent for years now. And you? With Jen?”

Rio felt claustrophobic and like she was gnawing on the bars of her enclosure all at once.

Agatha was pressed against her, so close that Rio was feeling hot again. Her hand was still curled around her neck, her finger looped around her necklace, and her body was pressed against her as much as it could be.

But her attention was on Wanda so Rio was left with nothing. She watched the workings of Agatha’s face, her profile still so close to Rio that she could count each freckle, the goddess that had done Agatha’s makeup had left them visible and Rio wanted to kiss her for it.

Just not as much as she wanted to kiss Agatha.

But Agatha turned slightly, slowly, and Rio saw the four freckles that haunted her thoughts because they were so precious, so delicious, so hers.

“Isn’t that right?”

Rio blinked, dropping her gaze from the freckles on Agatha’s nose to the lips that had just formed the question she was now expected to answer.

“What?”

“Alice is desperate to get us to work together.”

“Oh. Yes. Desperate.”

But a hand reached up between them and Rio found her head being turned to the side and her gaze was torn from Agatha. She felt fingers flex against the back of her neck as Wanda turned her to look over.

They were a tangle of limbs now.

To any unobservant outsider they were just a gaggle of women bending into one another to gossip. Three actresses leaning into each other, chatting about nothing.

Wanda was holding Rio’s cheek. Agatha’s arm was still across Rio with her wrist on Wanda. Her left hand was still against Rio’s neck. Rio’s hand holding her Globe was resting in Agatha’s lap, and still, warm and heavy against her, sat Wanda’s other hand on her knee.

“What’ll our little Christmas movie be? Twice now?”

“First didn’t count,” Rio said, half in the conversation and half now distracted by the thumb brushing small circles on her neck. “We barely had any scenes.”

“Well now we’ll be in almost every scene together. Christmas wives.”

Agatha’s fingers flexed.

“Christmas wives,” Rio repeated because it was easier than coming up with something herself.

“They wanted me for your role,” Agatha said, her tone still light, but Rio heard the pointedness of it as she broke Wanda’s hold and turned to her.

“But that was before Rio was attached.”

“Oh? I didn’t know that.”

Agatha hummed and dropped her gaze to where Wanda’s hand was against Rio’s leg for the first time. From this angle Rio couldn’t see her face anymore but her thumb had stopped moving against her neck.

“Second choice,” Agatha said as she turned back to Wanda and Wanda raised her brows, shocked by the insult. She pulled her hand back from Rio’s leg.

“Agatha,” Rio said quietly, making Agatha turn to her and arch a brow.

“It’s a good role,” Wanda was saying, missing the look exchanged between Rio and Agatha and none the wiser that Agatha was now toying with the chain of Rio’s necklace where it sat at the back of her neck.

“It might not look much, might look like just playing happy families but… and now Rio’s on board and we’re playing a lesbian couple with a kid. It’ll mean something to people.”

Agatha had looked away from Rio and Rio fell back into the struggle against temptation to not bite at her jaw.

“Sweet,” she said dismissively and tapped her finger on Wanda’s leg before she pulled slowly back and squeezed Rio’s knee where Wanda had just been holding her.

“I heard you might have scheduling conflicts.”

Rio tilted her head, turning curiously to Wanda, “You do?”

“Oh,” Wanda came back to herself, waving her hand absently, “Only last week my agent got a call about some reshoots needing done around the same time. Something about not being able to get the studio space later in the year for them. They’re working on it though it won’t be a problem.”

Rio raised her brows and felt Agatha pull away from beside her.

The Hollywood version of a game of Twister had ended.

And Rio wanted to spin the board again, but Agatha had pulled her hand away from her neck and the only thing now anchoring them were their thighs pressed together and Rio’s award resting in Agatha’s lap.

“How did you know about the scheduling issue?”

Agatha didn’t look around at Rio’s question and leant forward to pick up her champagne.

“It’s a small business in a small town. People talk.”

Rio watched her for a while, lost in her own mind until Wanda pulled her back. She was kissing her cheek, squeezing her knee again.

“I’m going to go mingle. I’ll catch you on the dance floor later?”

“Yeah,” Rio managed a smile and watched as Wanda shot Agatha a quick smile before she left, glancing over her shoulder at them both as she did.

“You could be nicer,” Rio said from the side of her mouth, moving her award back into her own lap.

Her other arm was still along the back of the seat, still so close to Agatha.

“She wants you,” Agatha said simply.

“We’re friends.”

“Unfortunately for her.”

Rio bit the inside of her cheek and glanced around to ensure no one would overhear when she said: “Jealous?”

Agatha turned to her then. Eyes so bright they were like kindling to Rio’s tortured heart.

“The necklace looks good on you,” Agatha said quietly and Rio knew she was giving her an answer without saying it and Rio wanted to kiss her for it.

“You’re pleased I’m wearing it?”

“Mm,” was all Agatha managed before they were descended upon by fellow partygoers.

Agatha put more distance between them then and leant away from Rio to engage someone else and Rio dutifully gave the director now talking to her her full attention.

Her award was back in her lap but her mind was elsewhere.

In any just world they’d have been a couple, able to lean into one another, able to kiss and touch and it not be a big deal.

But now Agatha was inches away from her on the couch and it would have been odd if Rio reached back out to her just to touch her.

The torture of being so close and yet so far could only last until Jen arrived at the scene to remove her client. Agatha barely turned to Rio, barely said goodbye, and then she was whisked off and Rio was left to fend for herself in a shark-infested pool of producers.

Alice soon took on Jen’s earlier role and came to rescue Rio and she found herself deposited in a much friendlier sphere of her fellow actors and then soon in amongst them on the dance floor.

Wanda was back again, back close, back encouraging her to enjoy and laugh and sing.

It felt good to have someone want to be close and not be scared by it. For that person to not pull away. For that person to actively be smiling for any camera that came past when their arms were around her.

Though Rio kept sweeping the room for Agatha, wondering if soon she’d feel her press against her, if soon she’d feel the music through Agatha’s body rather than someone else’s.

As her Golden Globe got passed around in a magnanimous and selfish move (it was getting too heavy to be constantly held), Rio spotted her through an opening in the crowd.

The most famous woman in the world was sitting with her manager and several Hollywood heavy hitters.

And yet.

She looked lonely.

Her eyes were no longer teasing or seductive. They were instead wide, soft, devastated.

Rio pulled from Wanda, pushed off clawing hands of her fellow dancers, intent on making sure Agatha never had to look that way again or feel the way she must be feeling.

She wanted to kiss it away, to press herself close enough that Agatha only saw and felt her and wouldn’t have to dwell in whatever she wouldn’t let Rio see. In that moment she felt like she could give everything. She felt like being close would cure Agatha of whatever ailed her.

Almost out of the sea of writhing bodies, Rio had her eyes on Agatha so missed the man approaching from the side. He blocked her view and Rio was polite enough to beg his excusal but not fast enough to see where Agatha had gone when she slipped past him.

She stood, staring at the place she’d been until hands and arms were around her again and she was pulled back into the throng to celebrate her win and to be celebrated in equal measure.

Hands and arms and willing smiles pulled her back onto the dance floor.

The music throbbed and the people around her buoyed her into existence, let alone the mood to dance. And she twisted and curled and jumped and screamed with everyone else.

Only she was the only one half there. The rest of her was wherever Agatha was.

An hour or so later Alice had found her again and was ushering her to their waiting car, whispering something about “leaving on a high”.

Their SUV was waiting and Rio clambered in, a little sweatier than when she’d arrived.

Her head was on the window and the gentle vibrations of the vehicle were soothing her when Alice spoke up.

“I was watching you with Agatha tonight.”

Focusing on the lights, Rio could almost control her heart rate.

“I think we should work the relationship with Wanda more. For the movie. For your future.”

“Alice.”

“Listen to me. You’re pining. I can see it now. Having someone else to focus your smiles and effort on… it’ll help. Plus Wanda’s a friend. She’ll have you. It’ll be easy.”

“No, Alice.”

“You don’t even have to do anything. Just hang out. We’ll call some paps. Besides, Wanda mentioned it earlier. She wants to do it.”

“No.”

“Rio.”

“I told you when we started all this; I’m not doing anything like that. I don’t care about it enough to lie.”

“She’s your friend. It’s not a-…”

“Alice, please.”

“I’m trying to help you. Agatha is… it’ll never happen, Rio. You need to move on. If I can’t make you date then I can at least make you fake it.”

“You can’t make me do anything.”

“I know. Just think about it.”

Rio closed her eyes as the flashing lights began to blur into one.

It was the last thing she remembered when she woke the next day, in her pyjamas, alone in her bed.

Chapter End Notes

For those of you who’ve read Rented Hearts: this Wanda is my apology for what I did to her in RH. She’s a sweetheart in this, make no mistake.

Up next: more Jen, more Ralph, some Nicky, and a trip to London for the BAFTAs. And dare I say: more angst.

Chapter 20: The Accolade

Chapter Summary

Nominations are out.

Rio is stuck between a rock and a Ralph place.

Chapter Notes

Don’t be mad at me okay thanks x

See the end of the chapter for more notes

I am beyond honored, beyond shocked, beyond words. I’m so grateful to the academy for recognizing this incredible team of performers, artists, and creators. I’m overwhelmed with the love I have for all of the people I share this honor with. I love you all. Te quiero todo.

Rio’s post got four million likes.

I am extremely honored to have been recognized by The Academy among these other extraordinary actresses. This role meant the world to me. To give a voice to the women who have suffered the unimaginable will forever be the honor of my life. To the wonderful team of creatives behind the scenes and in front of the camera: I can’t wait to celebrate with you all. What a dream.

Agatha’s post got twelve million likes.

Agatha’s text came in thirty seconds after the nominations were read out and Rio had, for the first time in her life, been focused on her phone during the announcement. She’d hoped Agatha would contact her.

1:02pm
Agatha Harkness: Baby’s first nomination.

1:03pm
Rio Vidal: 4 really is greedy

1:05pm
Agatha Vidal: It’s on my jersey, honey. You predicted it yourself.

1:05pm
Rio Vidal: Should have put 69 on there

1:27pm
Agatha Harkness: Should have.

1:27pm
Rio Vidal: Come over. I have maybe ten minutes of time that Alice hasn’t booked out. I’ll shake Alice off and we can celebrate.

1:28pm
Agatha Harkness: You think Jen isn’t keeping me just as busy?

1:28pm
Rio Vidal: I miss you.

Rio had arrived home to a bouquet of flowers with a note: Rio, So deserved. Agatha.

The bouquet was the biggest and most beautiful of the others that had arrived and filled the ground floor of Rio’s little villa. Or maybe Rio was just that in love.

Rio had sent Agatha a bouquet of mostly purple flowers. She’d arranged it days ago, knowing there was no chance she wouldn’t be nominated. And her note had read:

‘Agatha,
Estoy de rodillas por ti.
Rio x’

The Oscar nominations came out not long after the BAFTAs and the SAGs.

Both Rio and Agatha got into all three.

Wanda got into two; missing the SAG.

Rio’s feet didn’t touch the floor.

And Alice hadn’t given her a second to breathe. She’d been on her all day every day.

So much so that she didn’t know what day it was or where she was at any given moment. But she got through. With the help of coffee and an internal countdown to when she could see Agatha again.

She’d tried to call her a handful of times since the Globes but had only ever reached her voicemail and occasionally received a text an hour later apologising or telling her she was busy or she couldn’t talk now.

Rio missed her endlessly during this period.

The only respite she’d had in all this time was the flight over to London. Alice was fast asleep in her little cubby and so Rio had peace for the first time.

She drank red wine and watched all the movies she hadn’t watched in months because she’d had no time and no energy.

But Rio didn’t sleep.

Because she knew who she was seeing just hours after they touched down at Heathrow.

After the Globes the internet had been abuzz with excitement over the awards race hotting up. But a large and vocal majority had focused more on the photos that emerged after the awards had gone out.

Pictures appeared everywhere from TMZ to fan accounts online of the three way tête-à-tête between Rio, Wanda, and Agatha. Rumours began circulating that Rio and Wanda were now an item, and Agatha more of a vocal ally than she’d ever appeared to be before.

Wanda had used this newfound interest in her and Rio to try and convince her friend they should play into it but so far Rio hadn’t budged. Even with Alice on Wanda’s side.

Rio hadn’t heard from Agatha much during this time; at least not since the texts after the Oscar nominations came out. She relied instead on a steady stream of updates from Alice. And that’s how she found out that they’d all be arriving the same day in London, that Agatha was bringing Ralph and Nicky, and that a dinner at the Chiltern Firehouse had been booked for the day they arrived.

But according to Alice - again, via Jen - she was just as busy as Rio was. Only Agatha was also juggling Nicky. Which was the reason Nicky was coming to London. Alongside his father and his nanny.

Though thoughts of seeing the shy little boy did calm her rising disgust at having to spend at least two evenings watching Ralph with Agatha, most of Rio’s nervous energy was still focused on the man she’d now decided she hated with almost as much passion as she loved his wife.

She’d seen pictures of him and Agatha online in the time between the Globes and now.

Carefully planned by Jen, she had to assume.

And on one particularly terrible day she’d got high and googled photos of their wedding. She’d stared at images of Agatha’s best Hollywood smile in a Ralph Lauren gown and felt sick with jealousy and then become paranoid that she’d somehow been caught looking at the photos in public. Though she was home alone. She’d decided never to touch that particular strain again.

But with Ralph still came Agatha. And Rio wanted more than anything to see her again, to be in her presence, to perhaps be able to touch her.

By the time they landed in Heathrow, Rio had had the majority of a bottle of red and was feeling a little better about their plans for the evening.

Though she was exhausted.

London was cold. Even for London. And Rio, now styled to the nines wherever she went, had a thick woollen coat to wrap herself in as someone took her bags for her and she and Alice were led through Arrivals, hurried through passport control, and out to a waiting car.

There were some paps, some fans, and Rio stopped for the latter but did her best to ignore the former.

“Doing good, Rio. Doing good.”

Alice was always there to reassure, always hovering even when the youngest and littlest of fans approached.

And Rio was pleased to have her back on side again.

Doing all this without her would have been untenable. But she’d shared a small piece of her struggle with her best friend now, which helped dull the pain, even if it didn’t eradicate it entirely.

“Two hours to shower and change and then we need to leave for dinner,” Alice said absently as she tapped away at her phone, no doubt responding to journalists as they whisked through the traffic to their hotel.

“I think I’ll soak in the bath,” Rio said, watching Alice with a small smile. “Maybe shoot up some heroin and kill some puppies.”

“Yeah, good idea.”

Rio rolled her eyes and snatched Alice’s phone from her hands.

“Hey!”

“You’re doing it again!”

Through the windscreen mirror their driver looked back at them and saw a very tiny woman scrabbling to wrestle with a movie star. He averted his gaze; anything other than driving to and from the assigned destination was above his pay grade.

Rio was laughing now, and relented, but only because Alice was going a little pink at the ears from her efforts and she was beginning to feel bad.

“I’m trying to keep your career afloat.”

“Oh my sinking career? My Oscar nomination not good enough?”

Alice looked up with a scowl at her grinning best friend and huffed as she returned back to her seat. “Do you know how many emails I get a day? Not to mention your socials. It’s exhausting and I don’t think-…”

“I know, I know. You organise and I show up. I get it. I’m teasing.”

“You’re giddy. And I know why.”

Rio’s smile faded a little and Alice met her with a steady gaze. “It’s been a couple weeks, that’s all. Which is why I think that-…”

“Don’t even say it.”

“She makes a good argument, Rio. The amount of press the three of you got from just those pictures. Her hand on your cheek almost broke the internet.”

Rio sighed and began to toy with her hair, “It’s not something I want to do.”

“Wanda wants it. And it’ll be good for the movie.”

Rio shook her head and turned to look out the window, “I’m not doing it, Alice. She’s my friend and people can write what they want about us online but I’m not playing up to it.”

“You do look hot together though.”

“Whatever,” Rio said with a huff and blindly slapped at Alice’s arm as she kept her gaze out the window.

“Apparently the kid’s excited to see you,” Alice said, returning her attention back to her phone. Rio bit her lip and shot a glance at her distracted best friend.

“How do you know?”

“Jen said.”

“Alice.”

Alice sighed and placed her phone down in her lap to focus properly on Rio. “Agatha told Jen and Jen told me.”

“When.”

“Maybe a week ago.”

“Why didn’t you say?”

“Rio, a lot of people are excited to see you. I forget.”

“This is Agatha’s kid, Alice. How could you forget?”

Alice blinked and Rio realised how pathetic she must have sounded. Especially to the ears of someone who had no idea of the depth of Rio’s true feelings, of what complicated situation she’d entangled herself in with Agatha.

“I just… I’m sorry. It wasn’t intentional.”

Rio turned away again, and they were both silent for the rest of the drive. Alice had returned to her emails and Rio returned to her pining. Neither was very happy about it.

They arrived at the Ritz just as the rain began. Rio was protected by a large golfing umbrella and she had to bundle Alice in beneath her arm to make sure she kept out of the rain too.

There was a lone photographer who’d braved the weather to snap photos of whatever stars were arriving for the BAFTAs and staying in the infamous hotel near the palace and Rio missed his shout over the wind: “Here to see Agatha?”

Check-in was easy, and Alice handled most of it, even providing Rio’s passport as she held back, keeping her eyes on the large and supercilious lobby around her in case Agatha happened to be loitering around one of the randomly placed chaises anywhere nearby.

But she wasn’t.

And Rio was almost relieved. She needed some time to relax before she faced Agatha. Especially before she faced her with Ralph on her arm.

She took the bath she’d told Alice she’d take once she got to her room - minus the heroin and canicide. And she stayed in it until the very last second, giving herself just twenty minutes to change before she knew Alice would be banging down her door.

Drying herself she put on a cotton-soft white t-shirt and a thick argyle sweater vest and straight cut blue jeans with black heeled boots. It was casual, and warm, and she applied just a base layer of makeup with mascara and a nude lipstick before she grabbed her jacket and bag and waited obediently for Alice to arrive.

Alice had dressed a little fancier than Rio with a new shade of lipstick to boot but Rio didn’t comment other than to say she looked good and Jen would be beside herself.

They made their way to the restaurant in the same chauffeured car and Rio began to feel more and more nervous as the minutes went by and she found that she’d reached for Alice’s hand, which was originally met with resistance as Alice continued to try and work but she soon gave in upon seeing Rio’s pale face.

For the two weeks between the Golden Globes and the journey to the restaurant, Rio had thought every day of the look in Agatha’s eyes the last time she’d seen her.

Those eyes haunted her. Because it was Agatha at her most unguarded. Agatha telling her how she felt. Agatha who was usually so unreachable suddenly out in the open.

And Rio knew it was because Agatha felt trapped. So she waited. Quietly. Patiently. Hoping Agatha might be ready.

The situation outside the restaurant was a little different to the one outside the hotel. There were more paps, more cameras locked and loaded, and Rio guessed Agatha’s presence had already been let slip to the bastards holding them.

Rio and Alice made their way in with only a little fuss, keeping their heads down and their faces as neutral as possible and when they got out of the rain and into the warm embrace of the building, Rio released a breath she didn’t know she’d been holding.

They shrugged off their jackets and the concierge showed them to the table in the busy restaurant and Rio locked eyes with the woman she’d thought of almost every second of her busy days.

This Agatha was dressed down from the last time she saw her.

She wore a deep brown knit jumper, dark jeans, dark boots. She was standing to greet them. She was looking at Rio. She was smiling. She was reaching for her and Rio was back in her arms for the first time in what felt like forever.

Rio could breathe again.

“Hey,” she said quietly, coolly, as if hugging Agatha meant nothing to her, as if the squeeze around her shoulders was nothing and her own arms that squeezed Agatha’s waist were so used to it that it meant as little as if Agatha were anyone, and not Rio’s constant obsession.

But Agatha was moving on before she even said anything and Rio was left with a rush of cold air as Agatha pulled away only to be replaced by Jen two seconds later.

“Ah the golden girl has arrived,” Jen said close to Rio’s ear but gave her a quick squeeze all the same.

“Lovely to see you too, Jennifer.”

Rio pulled away with a small smile then and turned to the little boy standing just beside his mother, smiling goofily up at her.

“Hey, kid,” Rio said warmly, able to brush aside her desire to wrap her arms around Agatha again as she caught Nicky’s eyes.

“Holy shit,” Alice mumbled from somewhere behind her as Rio moved to give Nicky a hug. “I mean, holy shit. It’s way clearer in person.”

Rio hummed as Nicky said a slightly muffled “hi Rio” and she kissed the top of his head, briefly catching Agatha’s eyes as she released him and straightened out. To her surprise it was then that Agatha spoke to her, a barely whispered “hi” that made Rio blush where she stood.

“No one’s gonna comment on this?”

“Alice,” Rio said softly as she turned to her friend and saw what she assumed would be happening.

Alice was staring at Nicky now back at Agatha’s side, now holding her hand and looking serious.

“Babe,” Jen said quickly, tugging Alice to sit down at her side, “How was your flight?”

Rio bit down on her lip and turned to the next person she was yet to greet and smiled tightly at Ralph as he raised his glass to her, but didn’t get up, “Rio. Congrats on the nomination.”

“Thank you.”

Agatha moved past her and Rio felt the unmistakeable brush of a hand along her lower back and she was shocked into movement because of it and took a seat next to Nicky, the only seat now available at the table.

In their little table of six Rio had the undeniable pleasure of being as far from Ralph as possible. He sat opposite Agatha, on the opposite side, and Rio was pleased that he, and now Jen and Alice, were on the outside of the table, where she with Nicky and Agatha, had the booth side.

Though she’d assumed this had been Agatha’s choice and not Ralph being gentlemanly.

Before conversation could be picked up again, Rio felt a light kick to her shin and she looked up to see Alice making eyes at her and motioning with her head to Nicky. Rio cleared her throat in warning but said nothing, hoping Alice would drop it for fear she’d upset the boy.

Let alone Ralph.

“So,” Ralph said as if this were his table to command, as if everyone were hanging on his every word.

“How was the flight?”

Nicky fidgeted a little beside Rio and Rio glanced over to see he was toying with the menu on the table and another glance told her the reason for that: Alice was staring at him.

She kicked Alice much harder than Alice had kicked her.

“Ow, fuck!”

Rio shot her a look and Alice mumbled, “Sorry,” and had the humility to look ashamed of herself.

“The flight was fine. Long. How was yours?” Rio prided herself on being able to maintain a conversation, even if it were with a prick.

“Well, same length as yours,” Ralph said with a grin that Rio was sure would have floored any woman with even an inkling of attraction to men.

God, Rio hated him.

“Nicky and I watched movies, didn’t we honey?” Rio turned slowly from where she’d been smiling falsely at Ralph to look at Agatha whose arm she was thrilled to notice was along the back of the booth just inches from her shoulder.

She settled back a little and wished she could lean in to see if Agatha would touch her. She just about managed to hold herself back from it.

“Nevermind that,” Jen said with a wave of her hand that acted as a flyswatter on the conversation. “I want to talk tomorrow night: the two of you. Preferably without Wanda. Candids. We’re going to make it happen.”

Rio raised her brows and turned to Alice to see her reaction to this and saw her best friend beaming in surprise at her girlfriend.

“Seriously?!”

Jen huffed.

Alice practically squealed.

Agatha had leant over to nudge Rio’s shoulder.

Ralph knocked back his whiskey and clicked for a waiter to bring another.

“Didn’t I tell you?” Agatha asked with a smirk as Rio turned to her, unable to stop thinking about the fact that Agatha’s hand was still on her.

“Jen’s changed her mind about you.”

“It’s temporary,” Jen was now pointing at Rio across the table, narrowing her gaze at her even as Agatha squeezed her shoulder and Alice continued to grin.

“Only because we’re controlling the narrative.”

“Oh?” Rio shot a quick glance at Agatha but relaxed when she saw she looked amused rather than worried.

“The narrative that suggests that it’s pretty damn good for Agatha to be friends with an up and coming lesbian. It took me a while to get here but-…”

“An ‘up and coming lesbian’ makes it sound like Rio’s just worked out what her fingers do.”

Agatha cleared her throat and Alice glanced at Nicky who seemed both nonplussed and a little confused, “Sorry.”

“Actress, whatever. Gay actress.”

“Can we not. Nicky’s here.”

Four sets of eyes swivelled to Ralph and Rio wanted to jam her knife into his throat.

Agatha pulled her hand away from her.

“Look,” Jen said, her hands raised and her gaze briefly on Agatha as if assessing the danger levels already. “It’s just until the Oscars are over. A few nice shots. Get some social kudos and then we’ll be done.”

“Is that right?” Rio asked a little more harshly than she meant to, her mind shooting daggers at the man now not thanking the waiter for delivering his drink.

“Jesus, Rio. This is what you wanted.”

“It’s what Alice wanted. I don’t do PR relationships.”

“What does that mean?” Agatha asked suddenly, watching Rio with a frown, her arm now draped over Nicky’s shoulders.

“Are we ready to order drinks?”

The waiter had arrived and saved Rio’s life. Rio cleared her throat and just as she was about to reach for the drinks menu Ralph spoke again: “Oh a Pinto Noir for this one.”

Rio’s jaw almost came off its hinges and she stared across at the man now smirking at her, his fucking pinky raised as he sipped his fucking drink.

If Nicky hadn’t been beside her she’d have launched herself at him. But a foot was nudging her ankle and she tore her gaze from him to Alice as Jen, clearly also having decided to ignore Ralph, gave her order.

Alice just shook her head a little and Rio dropped her gaze to her menu, her teeth clenched so tightly in her mouth she thought she’d never be able to open it again.

“Rio will have the Barolo. Actually, make it a bottle. I’ll have it too. And a coke.”

Rio didn’t acknowledge Agatha ordering for her but she did look back up to Ralph and saw him watching her still and she felt like was going to explode from the look on his face.

He hated her, that much she could tell.

But he also looked smug, like he’d won something over on her.

She shut her menu.

“Sauvignon for me please,” Alice said after clearing her throat quietly.

The waiter nodded and Rio stood as he left, “Excuse me, I’ll be right back.”

She grabbed her purse and strode away as quickly as she could, desperate to have a second to breathe away from Agatha’s husband.

Only when in the bathroom did she slam her purse down and run her fingers through her hair and released the frustration by washing her hands in freezing cold water.

So intent on freezing her fingers off, she didn’t register the presence of a woman behind her.

“Rio Vidal?”

Rio jumped and smacked her thumb on the underside of the spout and grimaced out a “fuck!” as she ripped her hand up and cradled it. “Shit.”

“Here,” the woman moved forwards and took Rio’s wet hands in her own and Rio winced from the sharp pain in her thumb and the embarrassment of the situation.

“Sorry about that,” the woman murmured, and Rio shrugged a little, watching as her hand was turned over and the woman inspected her thumb that looked no worse for having just been smacked against the sharp edge of a very hefty metal tap.

“It’s okay. My fault.”

“Can you move it?”

Rio laughed softly and looked up then, sucking in a sharp breath when she saw the eyes of the woman now gently rubbing over her damp, sore thumb.

She was ridiculous looking. Like some kind of model. Some kind of gorgeous, better than other people, kind of model.

“I, yes, I can move it.”

Rio twitched her thumb beneath the woman’s hold and was graced with a a brilliant smile and Rio reflected it right back at her, momentarily stupefied by it.

It had been weeks since she’d so much as looked at anyone who wasn’t Agatha.

As if an alarm had gone off to tell Agatha that Rio was looking at another woman, she appeared in the bathroom suddenly. Rio missed the door opening, and only knew Agatha had arrived when she heard her name.

“Rio.”

And the wind was knocked out of her sails because a model was holding her hand and smiling at her but Agatha was there, she’d come looking, and Rio felt the pang of yearning more sharply than she’d felt her knuckle whack the metal.

Agatha was better than any model.

She turned to Agatha and saw that she was staring intently at where Rio’s hands were still being held.

“Jesus. Agatha Harkness.”

Blue eyes flashed up to look at the woman in front of Rio and Rio worried for this girl suddenly at the look on Agatha’s face.

“And you are?”

Rio bit her lip as Agatha The Ice Queen Harkness stared this woman down.

“Felicity,” the woman said with that same dazzling grin that had worked on Rio but was decidedly not working on Agatha.

Rio pulled her hands away gently and the woman turned back to her with raised brows, reaching back out for Rio’s injured hand. From the corner of her eye, Rio saw Agatha move over.

“I’m fine, really.”

But Agatha was taking her hand away from the woman’s hold and cradling it gently in her own, turning it over to see where Rio had injured herself.

“What happened?”

“Nothing,” Rio said softly, releasing an embarrassed huff even as the gentleness of Agatha’s touch made her whole body warm.

“She smacked her hand on the tap,” the woman said in a crisp English accent even as Agatha moved between them and blocked the stranger from Rio.

“It’s really fine,” Rio protested, shooting the woman a small smile before she returned her attention to Agatha who was now gently pressing on the bend of her thumb, kneading it until she found the: “ah!”

“It’s not fine,” Agatha concluded with a frown, shooting Rio a look before returning her attention back to her hand.

“Is there anything I can do?”

The poor woman moved around to stand beside the two actresses and Rio felt suddenly sorry for her. “No, thank you though. Really, I’m fine.”

“Well, maybe I could just get your number instead? Check in on your hand a little later?”

Agatha looked up, and Rio bit her tongue.

“I’m actually seeing someone,” Rio managed to get out, trying incredibly hard not to look at Agatha, not to see just how mad she was.

“Really?”

“Mmhm.”

“Damn. Okay, maybe you could just take it if it-…”

“She said no,” Agatha snapped suddenly, giving Rio the excuse to turn to look at her and she saw something glorious, something miraculous: Agatha was jealous.

No, Agatha was homicidal.

Rio swallowed down the urge to kiss her murderous face and turned back to the woman with an apologetic look, or one that she hoped was, at least.

“Sorry.”

The woman only smiled, shot Agatha a quick glance, and then grabbed her bag and left without even using the facilities she’d presumably come in here to use in the first place.

Only when they were alone again did Rio turn back to Agatha and saw that she looked no less furious. But the hold on her hand was still gentle, and Rio stepped a little closer as she said: “You okay in there?”

“Fine,” Agatha said quietly, clearing her throat as she leant around to turn on the water, running it over her fingers until it was warm, and then gently placing Rio’s thumb under it. “It’ll probably bruise, but it doesn’t feel broken.”

“Thank you, Dr Harkness.”

Agatha pursed her lips and Rio turned her hand over under the running water to lock her fingers with Agatha, proving her thumb was fine by rubbing it gently over Agatha’s.

Agatha didn’t do anything but let it happen and Rio was left to watch her clench and unclench her jaw as she worked through whatever she was thinking.

“Seeing someone?”

“What?”

“You’re seeing someone?”

Rio raised her brows and studied Agatha for a second, waiting for her to look up at her, and she did.

In the split second between looking furious still, staring at the water with blind rage, and looking up at Rio, her eyes became as soft as her touch.

“Agatha,” Rio breathed out softly, taking a step closer just as the door swung open and they were no longer alone.

Agatha had stepped back, dropped Rio’s hand, and turned away to face the mirror.

She cleared her throat and reached for a cloth to hand to Rio, “We should get back.”

“Agatha,” Rio whispered as her fingers curled slowly around the cloth offered to her. It was soft in her hand, but nothing to the delicate touches of Agatha a second ago.

“Not here,” Agatha breathed out, her fingers briefly making contact on the knitted vest Rio wore before she pulled back completely and made for the door.

Rio followed behind like lost kitten after tossing the cloth into the waiting basket.

It felt cruel, this obvious and visceral show from Agatha that she wanted her and then the immediate pull away, the knowledge that they couldn’t act on their feelings. And Rio approached the table again with a heaviness in her chest made only worse when she saw the back of Ralph’s stupid head.

Nicky looked up and smiled when she approached the bench and some of the heaviness lifted.

“All okay?” Alice asked with raised brows and Rio looked up and smiled tightly, “I hit my hand on the faucet. Agatha caught me and-…”

“Caught her flirting,” Agatha said and Rio turned sharply to her, feeling all eyes swivel not to her, but to Agatha, even as she kept her gaze on a tight jaw.

“I wasn’t-…”

“Rio,” Alice said in a softer, almost amused tone, “You hurt your hand because you were flirting?”

“Jesus, I hope you didn’t try anything in the bathroom like you did on the beach,” Jen added with a smirk. “I’ll rescind my offer of having access to Agatha if you-…”

“I didn’t,” Rio cut in sharply, less annoyed by Agatha thinking she was flirting than by Jen accusing her of shagging someone in the bathroom.

“Good,” Jen said as she sipped her newly-arrived wine.

“What happened on the beach?”

Rio looked away from Ralph and took a sip of her own wine as Agatha said: “Rio made a new friend. Friendly gal.”

“She is,” Nicky said quietly and Rio turned to smile down at him and nudged his shoulder gently.

“Anyway,” Alice was saying quickly to recover the conversation, “We should talk about something infinitely more interesting than Rio’s… friendliness.”

Rio shot her best friend a grateful smile and then settled back into the bench. She flexed her thumb and brushed her fingers over where she knew a bruise would soon blossom and saw a small hand reach for it too.

“Does it hurt?”

“A little.”

“Did mama kiss it better? That helps.”

Rio looked up and saw Agatha watching her and Nicky from the corner of her eye as Alice and Jen engaged Ralph in some shop talk.

“No. I think magic kisses only work when they’re given right away.”

Nicky hummed seriously as if mulling over the rules and regulations of the healing powers of magic kisses and then nodded and Rio shot him a smile as she asked, “Won any more championships since I last saw you?”

“No. I have scored a few times though.”

“Yeah? Of course you have! Best player on the team.”

“You know,” Agatha said as she leant into Nicky and Rio couldn’t help but lean in a little too. “Maybe now’s a good time to ask Rio your question, honey.”

“Oh,” Nicky said and shuffled around to look at Rio properly, “Mama said you’d come play again soon. Will you? Please?”

Rio chewed her lip and her eyes darted briefly up to Agatha who was purposefully not looking her way and she nodded as her gaze turned back to Nicky.

“Yes. Yes I’d love to.”

Nicky nodded and Agatha wrapped an arm around him and pulled him closer into her side, but Rio caught it, just briefly, she’d looked her way.

They locked eyes for only a second and Agatha let her in. She let her see how badly she felt, how desperate she was, and how this was killing her as much as it was killing Rio.

And suddenly the dull ache in her thumb meant nothing, the arrows slung her way when Agatha was jealous were soft caresses compared to this. Because this felt like she were being run over repeatedly by a truck.

So Rio turned away.

She took up her wine and focused on not reaching out and causing a scene; on not breaking up a marriage in the most public, but fastest way possible.

“Rio,” Rio looked up when she heard her name from the lips of public enemy number one.

She wished she hadn’t.

Ralph’s hand was outstretched towards Agatha, his fingers splayed out, expectant.

Agatha’s left hand, ringless, was toying with the stem of her glass.

“I hope you’re not putting false ideas into my son’s head about which team to support.”

Agatha still hadn’t taken his hand.

Nicky shifted beside her.

“Not this again,” Jen said with a roll of her eyes, swirling her glass where she looked between them, her gaze briefly flickering down to Ralph’s hand. “Heard enough about Nicky’s basketball team to last a lifetime.”

Rio raised her brows and sat back again, her eyes drifting back to Ralph’s hand and making sure he saw it before she looked up again.

“Actually we’ve agreed I’ll come over soon to play ball.”

“Is that right?”

Ralph pulled his hand back and Rio felt a flash of triumph deep within her chest. Agatha would take her hand.

“Perhaps I’ll check my schedule and I can-…”

“No daddy.”

Rio and Agatha looked at the same time down at the little boy with a big frown and Rio felt sick with the prospect of it. Of Nicky looking distressed, of Agatha pulling him closer as she leant back a little and her chin raised to Ralph.

“I think maybe the Celtics fans should stick together.”

Rio shot a look at Alice and saw something turning in her brain, her brow furrowed, her fingers curling and uncurling around the cup of her wine.

And Jen beside her was watching Agatha like a hawk, her jaw tight as she waited for the retort from the Bulls fan beside her.

“Fine. Wouldn’t look good to destroy a girl on the court anyway.”

Rio couldn’t help the scoff that left her mouth then, and she became defensive, cocky, as she turned her body and raised her arm over the back of the bench.

“Oh you think-…?”

“Honey,” Agatha said quickly, but it wasn’t Rio she was speaking to. She reached out to Ralph and simultaneously stabbed Rio in the heart.

Alice was kicking Rio under the table so much that Rio could only imagine the bruises that would be blossoming by morning.

“Maybe let’s leave the basketball talk for now.”

And Ralph took Agatha’s hand and Rio had to look away again, had to tuck her legs beneath the bench so Alice couldn’t reach her, had to remove her arm from the back of the seat and drink down her full glass of red.

The conversation moved on but Rio didn’t.

Her gaze remained down for most of the meal, and she spoke only when spoken to or when Alice managed to kick her shin or nudge her hand.

She found it easier to speak to Nicky; whom she shared a bowl of fries with, always giving him the biggest ones.

But she didn’t look at Agatha again.

Ralph continued to drink his whiskeys and Rio felt like she could smell his breath at this point, his bark of a laugh offensive to her ears, and the hand that now gesticulated arrogantly and had once held Agatha’s over the table, making her want to scream with every movement.

It was getting late and the wine was still flowing but Rio had given up drinking, deciding it wasn’t even numbing anymore.

And Nicky beside her was quieter again and soon leaning against her side, toying with his napkin in his lap.

“You know what makes me feel better when I’m tired?”

“What?”

“A chocolate milkshake. You know they make the best ones in the world here, right?”

Nicky looked up and Rio grinned and for a second she felt a little better about the whole situation.

Ralph hadn’t made Nicky grin like that. He’d barely looked at him all night.

“Hey,” Agatha said, and Rio knew instinctively she was talking to her so she looked up for the first time in over an hour.

“Maybe if you go to the bar they’ll make the special ones. I don’t think they bring the best ones to the table.”

If Rio were being dismissed, it didn’t feel like it. It felt instead like Agatha were asking her a favour, and she was more than willing to accept.

She nodded, caught the slight twitch in Agatha’s lips, and slid from the bench to take Nicky’s hand and pull him away with her to the bar.

As they stepped away she overheard Alice whisper, “Agatha, are you sure you didn’t steal that kid from Rio? Did she have a baby and not tell me?”

Rio hurried Nicky along, ignoring the eyes on her from all sides as they went past.

Fame came with a lot of pros but a big con was being on show all the time. And usually, it was manageable. But with a kid in tow, especially one that belonged to the woman she felt sick over, it felt dangerous.

As they arrived at the bar Rio manoeuvred them to a quieter section near the wall so Nicky would be sandwiched between her and the protection of the building itself.

It was cosy, calmer here than at the table, where tempers had been simmering since Ralph’s proclamation that Rio was trying to influence her son in some way.

Agatha had been a stoic presence, at some points torn between ripping Ralph’s head off and tempering him, and Rio had lost count of how many times she’d called him “honey”.

“Miss? I’m sorry, we can’t let children sit at the bar.”

But Rio was prepared for this. She put on her best movie star smile and placed her hand on the bar before her as Nicky stood by her side.

“I was hoping you’d make an exception. See, my friend here just got off a flight from the states and the only magical cure for tiredness at this time of night is the best chocolate milkshake in the world.”

The bar manager pressed his lips together and Rio knew he was fighting a smile. He leant forwards and peered down at Nicky.

Rio looked down at him too and saw that he looked shy and was hiding behind the hair now falling across his eyes.

Rio brushed it aside for him.

“Well… we do make the best milkshakes in the world, young man. One chocolate milkshake coming right up, Miss Vidal.”

“Make that two please,” Rio smiled as she helped Nicky jump onto the bar stool.

“Of course.”

Rio thanked the man with a gracious smile and settled on her own stool beside Nicky.

“Told you they were the best.”

Nicky smiled and began toying with the sleeves of his sweater and Rio turned over her shoulder to look at the little table they’d just left behind.

She caught Agatha’s eye where she was watching them closely and smiled before she turned back to Nicky and said: “You know, no one’s ever bought me a Celtics scarf before. I loved it so much.”

“Really?”

“Uh huh.”

“Mama said you would.”

Rio grinned and tilted her head as she began to fiddle with the napkin laid out before her. “She is a very smart woman.”

“Very smart,” Nicky agreed, straightening up to see what Rio was doing with the napkin.

“What is that?”

“Hmm?” Rio hummed quietly as she stuck her tongue between her teeth and tried to concentrate, ignoring the sharp pain of her thumb as she worked the light fabric. “Well, I learnt a little while ago how to make flowers so I’m just trying to remember.”

Nicky only nodded and watched for a while, until Rio produced what was, under no circumstances whatsoever, a flower.

“I think I forgot,” she held up her creation and pulled a face that made the little boy giggle and she found herself laughing with him just as the best milkshakes in the world arrived.

They both thanked the barman and Rio caught him winking at her in a way that didn’t feel predatory but made her feel like just perhaps they were about to have the best milkshakes in the world.

She turned to Nicky first and helped him with his straw so he could reach the drink without spilling it everywhere and then nudged her glass with his: “Cheers!”

“Cheers!” Nicky repeated before he proceeded to drink down half of his milkshake in one swift go.

“Woah, woah, calm down.”

Nicky grinned when he stopped and Rio rolled her eyes, pleased the best milkshake in the world was going down well.

They were silent for a while, Rio quietly counting how many years it had been since she’d actually had a chocolate milkshake, let alone the best one in the world, but Nicky interrupted her thoughts with a question of his own:

“Do we look the same?”

The question came from nowhere, and Rio almost choked on her own shake and grabbed her attempt at a napkin flower to cover her mouth quickly, just in case.

“Umm. Do you think we do?”

“No.”

Rio nodded thoughtfully, recovering somewhat, “Why do you ask?”

“A boy at school said his mom said we did.”

Rio hummed quietly, watching the thoughts swirl across a serious face. “Well I think we look a little similar, but not the same.”

Nicky nodded and pulled his shake closer towards him.

“Did you ask your mom about it?”

“She said I was very handsome and you are very beautiful and because of that we look a little the same.”

Rio smiled. “Well I don’t mind looking a little like you. Do you mind looking a little like me?”

“No,” Nicky said, pulling the straw out from between his teeth.

Rio grinned and turned to take a sip of her own shake.

This really was the best milkshake in the world.

As she was placing her glass back down a hand found her lower back and she turned to find the person she’d hoped she would standing between the two stools.

“So? Is it the best milkshake in the world?”

“Yes, mama,” Nicky grinned and offered the straw up to Agatha who leant in to take some, humming thoughtfully as she did.

“Not bad. Not bad. And Rio? What does yours taste like?”

Rio arched a brow and bit down on her lip, pulling her milkshake away from Agatha’s now grabbing hand, “The same as Nicky’s.”

“A little the same,” Nicky said with a laugh.

“No, exactly the same,” Rio grinned as she pulled it further away from Agatha.

“You won’t let me try?”

Agatha’s hand was now just resting on her thigh where Rio had turned to the side and maybe it was the sugar, maybe it was just because they were alone again, maybe it was because Agatha was her soft self once more, but she felt happy for the first time all evening.

“Fine,” she said as she held out her glass and offered the straw up. “But don’t drink it all.”

Agatha narrowed her eyes and leant in to try the shake and to Rio’s utter joy she squeezed her thigh as she did, confident Nicky would be too focused on his mom stealing her friend’s drink to notice.

“Delicious,” she announced as she pulled back with a grin, “Nicky was right, they are a little the same.”

“Whatever,” Rio said with a smirk as Agatha moved her hand back again.

Agatha raised her brows and turned to her son again, brushing his hair back from his face gently. “You two okay over here? Having fun?”

“Yeah. Rio was trying to make a flower but it was very bad.”

Rio rolled her eyes and huffed dramatically, “It wasn’t that bad.”

“It was!” Nicky laughed out and Rio huffed again.

“Making flowers?” Rio looked up and caught Agatha’s eye and blushed a little, as she said: “a trick I learned a while back.”

“I remember.”

Rio sucked in a short breath then and caught Agatha’s gaze drop to her lips and she forgot all about Ralph, or about the fact that they were in public, and simply stared up at her, unwavering in her gaze until Nicky spoke up.

“Maybe you can try again with a green one. It’s lucky, you said so.”

“Maybe,” Rio smiled, turning back to Nicky and then busying herself with her straw as she finished her milkshake.

“I think blue ones are also nice.”

Rio choked on the last of her shake and Agatha slapped her back for her, eventually rubbing it in small circles as she came back to herself.

“That’s… yes… blue’s good,” she coughed out, embarrassed that she wasn’t just a woman choking at the bar, she was a movie star choking at the bar, which meant everyone was looking.

Months.

It was months ago that Rio had made Agatha that little blue flower.

Agatha who received flowers just for walking down the street, just for breathing, remembered the colour of the tiny, origami flower Rio had once made her.

It made her feel dizzy where she sat.

“We should go back,” Agatha said once Rio no longer looked like she was going to collapse.

Nicky turned away and began to finish off his shake faster than he’d begun it and Rio just turned to Agatha, caught her gaze, and saw again the sadness she’d seen briefly earlier and had spotted at the Globes.

“How is it over there?”

“A little the same.”

Rio smiled and rolled her eyes, poking at Agatha’s side gently.

“You’re staying at the Ritz?”

“Same floor as you.”

“How do you-…?”

But Nicky was slipping from his stool, standing with his hand in his mother’s and offering his other to Rio and Rio wouldn’t have refused it for the world.

They walked back, a happy trio, a trio that turned many heads and created many whispers, and Rio’s mood sank the closer and closer they go back to the table.

Ralph had his hand in the air and was clicking again.

Rio murdered him in her mind.

They slid in one by one into the booth and Nicky went to sit in Agatha’s lap, resting his head beneath her chin and smiling at Rio. Rio smiled back and she settled back into her seat a little closer to Agatha because of it.

“He’s too old for that,” came the voice of Ralph, who’d stopped clicking now he’d got the attention of one of the waiters.

“Ralph,” Agatha said simply, adjusting so her cheek was on the back of Nicky’s head.

“I’m telling you, you coddle him. He’ll grow up to be-…”

“What?” Agatha said sharply, her hold visibly tightening on Nicky. Rio moved a little closer.

“I for one,” Jen interjected, “Would love to be cuddled up in Agatha’s arms.” She made a very bad job of making a noise that would convince anyone she was telling the truth. “Mm, mm, mm. Ralph’s just jealous you’re not in his, Agatha.”

Rio looked over and saw that Agatha’s eyes were on Ralph but that Ralph was looking away now, preoccupied with the whisky being placed before him.

“Hey,” Rio said, ignoring the warning look shot her way by Alice. “Y’know who also gives really good hugs?”

“Who?” Nicky asked quietly, some of his previous light dimmed a little.

“Jen. She loves hugs. Especially those hugs where your hands are a little sticky from eating chocolate and you just smush yourself against her.”

“Rio Vidal, I am going to murder you.”

Rio made a face and wriggled her fingers in front of Nicky to make him laugh and Agatha pulled back to watch as Rio successfully got her son to giggle.

“You’re an idiot.”

“She’s a monster,” Jen added.

And Rio only grinned because Nicky was grinning again and Ralph was busy looking around for some girl to ogle.

And Agatha reached for her, squeezed her arm, and Rio turned back to her and saw something that made her understand what her mother meant when she said that pictures of Nuestra Señora y el Santo Niño filled her with great sorrow and great faith.

The picture before her was the perfect Pietà.

Agatha was cradling Nicky and looking at Rio with such an intense, open gaze, that Rio felt blessed just to see it. She yearned to reach for her, to brush the hair that had fallen into her face back, to cradle her cheek, to kiss her forehead and wrap her arms around them both.

“She’s silly,” Nicky said quietly, rubbing at his eyes as he did it and smiled.

“Sugar crash,” Agatha murmured against his hair, “that was quick.”

“I’m not long behind him.”

“No more room at the inn, I’m afraid,” Agatha said quietly, her brows raising a little as she motioned to the little boy in her arms with her head.

“Shame.”

Agatha hummed and turned around, hiding her smile in Nicky’s hair.

“Another bottle?” Jen asked with raised brows, picking the white wine she’d been sharing with Alice up and wriggling it.

“Not for me,” Agatha said and Rio shook her head too.

“I’ll take some.”

“I’ll share,” Ralph said, his attention back on the table now more alcohol was being offered.

“Oh good,” Jen deadpanned and Rio had to fight her smirk at her tone.

“You wanna get out of here?”

Rio was still struggling to hide her smirk and so didn’t look at Agatha and instead just nodded, reaching down to grab her purse.

“Rio,” Alice said quickly and Rio looked up in surprise. “Seven is the latest you can sleep in. Okay? We have things to do.”

Rio rolled her eyes but stood and went to kiss Alice’s cheek, “Yeah, yeah.”

She leant in on the other side to kiss Jen’s and found herself unable to pull up, Jen’s hand on the side of her head. In front of her Agatha was moving with a sleepy Nicky and she felt Alice turn curiously to them at her side.

“The photos. Rio. You can have them tomorrow. Just… focus your smiles a little more on Agatha rather than Wanda for me.”

Rio frowned in confusion and turned her head towards Jen, so close she could see the fine lines on her brow that she spent a lot of time and money getting rid of. She could see why Alice was obsessed with her.

“Seriously?”

“Rio,” Agatha said from beside the table, her hands on Nicky’s shoulders where they stood. “Ready?”

Rio continued to frown at Jennifer but she hadn’t answered her, was instead tapping her cheek, and smiling up at her. But she pulled away and watched Jen grin as she did so.

She made to move off but was distracted briefly by the sight of Ralph reaching to ruffle Nicky’s hair and then take hold of Agatha’s wrist.

Rio grit her teeth and turned from the sight of Agatha leaning towards him for fear she’d see something she’d never be able to unsee.

She got to the maitre d’ before Agatha and Nicky had and requested their jackets, her fingers tapping a random pattern as she tried to forget that whilst she was going home with Agatha, she wasn’t going home with Agatha.

Ralph would be.

Ralph who’d probably just kissed Agatha.

A hand curled around her elbow and Rio glanced to see Agatha there but didn’t look around properly. Neither of them said anything but Agatha held on until their jackets arrived and she had to let go to help Nicky into his then accept the help of the staff member now holding hers out.

Rio did the same and then made for the door. She stepped outside without thinking, walking into the dark, rainy night without checking.

The first flash was enough for her to realise her mistake.

The second was enough to make her turn.

The third was when her wide eyes fell to Agatha behind her.

“Rio,” Agatha said quickly, and Rio spotted the maitre d’ stepping out around Agatha, barely large enough to form the barricade they needed. “Turn. Go.”

Rio froze as the flashes continued and Agatha took her hand as she stepped past with Nicky pressed in front of her and only then did Rio snapped back into her right mind and followed quickly behind Agatha, squeezing her hand firmly.

When they were in the car and the doors were closed Rio managed to get out: “Fuck. Fuck! I forgot I-…”

And then she turned and saw Nicky staring at her and Agatha frowning, busying herself with tugging Nicky’s jacket closer around him, “It’s fine.”

“It’s not. Ralph should have helped. He should have-… ,” but she stopped herself from the tirade she was on the precipice of, holding herself back for the sake of the little boy the other side of Agatha.

Rio huffed and ran her hands through her hair, “Sorry for the bad language, kid.”

Nicky only smiled sleepily and Agatha took her hand so she couldn’t play with her hair anymore and she held it in her lap, firmly, proudly, apparently not worried that Nicky could see it. And Nicky didn’t look concerned about it at all.

“They can be bad in London,” Agatha explained with that same frown, “There’ll be more at the hotel.”

Rio nodded and looked around at Nicky before she moved her free hand to hold Agatha’s arm, “I’ll go first? Nicky can go behind me and-…”

“Rio.”

Blue eyes flashed to brown and Rio wanted to lean in properly, to rest their foreheads together, to kiss away the concern.

“Stop being so-…”

“What?”

Agatha just shook her head slightly, her frown returning as she looked away and Rio worried she were overstepping, caring too much about Nicky, about Agatha, but Agatha’s grip on her hand was still firm. She hadn’t stopped her thumb from brushing over the back of Rio’s hand, and she hadn’t moved her arm away where Rio still held it.

They rode mostly in silence and when they pulled up to the entrance Rio could squint through the dark windows to see the looming, ominous figures of men waiting with large cameras.

Agatha released her hand after squeezing it and helped Nicky climb over her to wait beside Rio until they were ready to clamber out.

Someone opened the door for them and Rio slid quickly out, turning only to help Nicky and take his hand and forming a barrier between him and the flashing cameras until she felt Agatha step out behind them. As a trio they made their way into the hotel - Nicky sandwiched between them and this time more staff members helping, including one beast of a security guard who walloped a man trying to get in Rio’s face.

By the time they were in the calm of the hotel lobby, Rio’s heart rate felt less than steady. She turned to check on her charges and saw Agatha bending down to tug Nicky’s jacket into place where it had slipped in the rush and saw the damp hair that stuck to her face.

She looked wild and protective and then she was looking up at her and she looked exactly the same. Cautious baby blues scanned her over, detecting any harm, and in seeing none, she moved to adjust Rio’s collar and said in a low voice, “Thank you.”

Rio smiled a little and watched as Agatha’s gaze dropped to it and for a brief moment in time she thought she might kiss her. But instead she pulled away, leading Nicky to the elevator and Rio followed behind.

Inside the small space, Rio reached for Agatha’s hand again, out of sight from Nicky the other side of her. She interlinked their fingers and Agatha leant against her arm for the duration of the short ride to their floor.

Agatha let Nicky step out first and took advantage of their brief privacy to turn and kiss Rio’s cheek, pressing her nose against her warm skin briefly before she pulled away and followed her son out along the hallway.

And Rio followed behind, her eyes on Agatha as she sauntered down the hall, her back straight, her hands casually at her sides, her wild hair bouncing in waves across her back to the rhythm of each step.

It felt surreal sometimes, seeing Agatha like this. Like being a total outsider in her life. Someone who didn’t know how she sounded when she came, someone who couldn’t tell you the specific shade of blue her eyes were when she woke, someone who didn’t get access to her softness.
